titleStmt.title: The Woman's Prize, or The Tamer Tamed1611
titleStmt.author: Fletcher, John

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: The woman's prize: or, the tamer tamed.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Moroso, Sophocles, and Tranio, with rosemary, as from a wedding.

sp.speaker: Moroso.
sp.l: God give 'em joy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Amen, say I to:
The puddings now i'th proof; alas poor wench,
Through what a mine of patience must thou work,
Ere thou knowest good hour more?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis too true: certain,
Methinks her father has dealt harshly with her,
Exceeding harshly, and not like a father,
To match her to this dragon; I protest
I pity the poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Methinks now,
He's not so terrible as people think him.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: This old thief flatters, out of mere devotion,
To please the father for his second daughter.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But shall he have her?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, when I have Rome.
And yet the father's for him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I'll assure ye,
I hold him a good man.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes sure a wealthy,
But whether a good woman's man, is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Would 'twere no worse.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What though his other wife,
Out of her most abundant soberness,
Out of her daily hue and cries upon him,
(For sure she was a rebel) turned his temper,
And forced him blow as high as she? dost follow
He must retain that long since buried tempest,
To this soft maid?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I fear it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: So do I too:
And so far, that if God had made me woman,
And his wife that must be —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What would you do sir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I would learn to eat coals with an angry cat,
And spit fire at him: I would (To prevent him)
Do all the ramping, roaring tricks, a whore
Being drunk, and tumbling ripe, would tremble at:
There is no safety else, nor moral wisdom,
To be a wife, and his.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: So I should think too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For yet the bare remembrance of his first wife
(I tell ye on my knowledge, and a truth too)
Will make him start in's sleep, and very often
Cry out for cudgels, colstaves, any thing;
Hiding his breeches, out of fear her ghost
Should walk, and wear 'em yet. Since his first marriage,
He is no more the still Petruchio,
Than I am Babylon.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He's a good fellow,
And on my word I love him: but to think
A fit match for this tender soul —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His very frown, if she but say her prayers
Louder than men talk treason, makes him tinder;
The motion of a dial, when he's testy,
Is the same trouble to him as a waterwork;
She must do nothing of herself; not eat,
Drink, say sir how do ye, make her ready, unready,
Unless he bid her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He will bury her
Ten pound to twenty shillings, within these three weeks.

sp.speaker: Tra:
sp.l: I'll be your half.

div.stage: Enter Jaques with a pot of wine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: He loves her most extremely,
And so long 'twil be honeymoon. Now Jaques
You are a busy man I am sure.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes certain,
This old sport must have eggs,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Not yet this ten days.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Sweet gentlemen with muskadel.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's right sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: This fellow broods his master: speed ye Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: We shall be for you presently.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Your worships
Shall have it rich and neat: and of my conscience
As welcome as our lady day: oh my old sir,
When shall we see your worship run at ring?
That hour a standing were worth money

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Upon my little honesty, your mistress,
If I have any speculation, must think
This single thrumming of a fiddle,
Without a bow, but e'en poor sport.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You're merry.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Would I were wise too: so God bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The fellow tells you true. Exit Jaq.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: When is the day man?
Come, come, you'll steal a marriage.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay believe me:
But when her father pleases I am ready,
And all my friends shall know it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why not now?
One charge had served for both.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: There's reason in't.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Called Rowland.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Will ye walk?
They'll think we are lost: come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You have wiped him now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: So will he never the wench I hope.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I wish it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Now Livia, if you'll go away tonight ,
If your affections be not made of words.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I love you, and you know how dear Rowland,
Is there none near us? my affections ever
Have been your servants; with what superstition
I have ever sainted you —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why then take this way.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: 'Twill be a childish and a less prosperous course,
Than his that knows not care: why should we do
Our honest and our hearty love such wrong,
To overrun our fortunes?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Then you flatter.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Alas you know I cannot.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What hopes left else
But flying to enjoy ye?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: None so far,
For let it be admitted we have time,
And all things now in other expectation,
My father's bent against us; what but ruin,
Can such a by-way bring us? if your fears
Would let you look with my eyes, I would show you,
And certain, how our staying here would win us
A course, though somewhat longer, yet far surer.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And than Moroso has ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: No such matter:
For hold this certain, begging, stealing, whoring,
Selling, (Which is a sin unpardonable)
Of counterfeit cods, or musty English cracas,
Switches, or stones for th'toothache sooner finds me,
Then that drawn fox and Moroso.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But his money,
If wealth may win you —

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If a hog may be
High priest among the Jews: his money Rowland?
O love forgive me, what faith hast thou?
Why, can his money kiss me?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Behind,
Laid out upon a petticoat: or grasp me
While I cry, oh good thank you? of my troth
Thou mak'st me merry with thy fear: or lie with me,
As you may do? alas, what fools you men are?
His mouldy money? half a dozen riders,
That cannot sit but stamped fast to their saddles?
No Rowland, no man shall make use of me;
My beauty was born free, and free I'll give it
To him that loves, not buys me. You yet doubt me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot say I doubt ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Go thy ways,
Thou art the prettiest puling piece of passion:
I'faith I will not fail thee.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I had rather —

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Prithee believe me, if I do not carry it,
For both our goods —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But —

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What but?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I would tell you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I know all you can tell me; all's but this,
You would have me, and lie with me; is't not so?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Why you shall; will that content you? Go.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I am very loath to go. Enter Byancha, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Now of my conscience
Thou art an honest fellow: here's my sister;
Go, prithee go; this kiss, and credit me,
Ere I am three nights older, I am for thee:
You shall hear what I do.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell. Exit Rowland.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Alas poor fool, how it looks?
It would e'en hang itself, should I but cross it.
For pure love to the matter I must hatch it.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Nay never look for merry hour Maria,
If now you make it not; let not your blushes,
Your modesty, and tenderness of spirit,
Make you continual anvil to his anger:
Believe me, since his first wife set him going,
Nothing can bind his rage: take your own council,
You shall not say that I persuaded you.
But if you suffer him —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, shall I do it?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Have you a stomach to't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never showed it.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: 'Twill show the rarer, and the stronger in you.
But do not say I urged you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am perfect,
Like Curtius to redeem my country, have I
Leaped into this gulf of marriage, and I'll do it.
Farewell all poorer thoughts, but spite and anger,
Till I have wrought a miracle. Now cousin,
I am no more the gentle tame Maria;
Mistake me not; I have a new soul in me
Made of a northwind, nothing but tempest;
And like a tempest shall it make all ruins,
Till I have run my will out.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: This is brave now,
If you continue it; but your own will lead you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Adieu all tenderness, I dare continue;
Maids that are made of fears and modest blushes,
View me, and love example.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Here is your sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here is the brave old man's love.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That loves the young man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I and hold thee there wench: what a grief of heart is't,
When Paphos' rebels should up rouse old night,
To sweat against a cork; to lie and tell
The clock o'th longs, to rise sport-starved?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Dear sister,
Where have you been you talk thus?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why at church, wench;
Where I am tide to talk thus: I am a wife now.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: It seems so, and a modest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are an ass;
When thou art married once, thy modesty
Will never buy thee pins.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: 'Bless me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From what?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: From such a tame fool as our cousin Livia?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You are not mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes wench, and so must you be,
Or none of our acquaintance, mark me Livia.
Or indeed sit for our sex: 'tis bed time.
Pardon me yellow Hymen, that I mean
Thine offerings to protract, or to keep fasting
My valiant bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Whether will this woman?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You may perceive her end.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Or rather fear it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dare you be partner in't?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Leave it Maria,
I fear I have marked too much, for goodness leave it;
Divest you with obedient hands to bed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bed? No Livia, there are comets hang
Prodigious over that yet; there's a fellow
Must yet before I know that heat (Never start wench)
Be male a man, for yet he is a monster;
Here must his head be Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: Never hope it.
'Tis as easy with a sieve to scoop the ocean, as
To tame Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay: Lucina hear me,
Never unlock the treasure of my womb
For humane fruit, to make it capable;
Nor never with thy secret hand make brief
A mother's labour to me; if I do
Give way unto my married husbands will,
Or be a wife, in any thing but hopes,
Till I have made him easy as a child,
And tame as fear, he shall not win a smile,
Or a pleased look, from this austerity,
Though it would pull another jointure from him,
And make him every day another man;
And when I kiss him, till I have my will,
May I be barren of delights, and know
Only what pleasures are in dreams, and guesses.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A strange exordium.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: All the several wrongs
Done by imperious husbands to their wives
These thousand years and upwards, strengthen thee:
Thou hast a brave cause.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I'll do it bravely
Or may I knit my life out ever after.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: In what part of the world got she this spirit?
Yet pray Maria, look before you truly,
Besides the obedience of a wife,
Which you will find a heavy imputation,
Which yet I cannot think your own, it shows
So distant from your sweetness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis I swear.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Weigh but the person, and the hopes you have,
To work this desperate cure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A weaker subject
Would shame the end I aim at, disobedience.
You talk too tamely: by the faith I have
In mine own noble will, that childish woman
That lives a prisoner to her husband's pleasure,
Has lost her making, and becomes a beast,
Created for his use, not fellowship.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: His first wife said as much.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She was a fool,
And took a scurvy course; let her be named
'Mongst those that wish for things, but dare not do 'em:
I have a new dance for him.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Are you of this faith?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes truly, and will die in't.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Why then let's all wear breeches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now thou com'st near the nature of a woman;
Hang these tame hearted eyasses, that no sooner
See the lure out, and hear their husbands halla,
But cry like kites upon 'em: the free haggard
(Which is that woman, that hath wing, and knows it,
Spirit, and plume) will make an hundred checks,
To show her freedom, sail in every air,
And look out every pleasure; not regarding
I ure, nor quarry, till her pitch command
What she desires, making her foundered keeper
Be glad to fling out trains, and golden ones,
To take her down again.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You are learned sister;
Yet I say still take heed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A witty saying;
I'll tell thee Livia, had this fellow tired
As many wives as horses under him,
With spurring of their patience; had he got
A patent, with an office to reclaim us
Confirmed by parliament; had he all the malice
And subtlety of devils, or of us,
Or any thing that's worse than both.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Hey, heigh boys, this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Or could he
Cast his wives new again, like bells to make 'em
Sound to his will; or had the fearful name
Of the first breaker of wild women: yet,
Yet would I undertake this man, thus single,
And spite of all the freedom he has reached to,
Turn him and bend him as I list, and mould him
Into a babe again; that aged women,
Wanting both teeth and spleen, may master him.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou wilt be chronicled.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's all I aim at.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: I must confess, I do with all my heart
Hate an imperious husband, and in time
Might be so wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: To make him cuckold?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If he deserve it.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then I'll leave ye ladies.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou hast not so much noble anger in thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go sleep, go sleep, what we intend to do,
Lies not for such starved souls as thou hast Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good night: the bridegroom will be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's more than you know.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If ye work upon him,
As you have promised, ye may give example,
Which no doubt will be followed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Good night: we'll trouble you no further.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If you intend no good, pray do no harm.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: None, but pray for you. Exit Livia.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: 'Cheer wench?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now Byancha,
Those wits we have let's wind 'em to the height,
My rest is up wench, and I pull for that
Will make me ever famous. They that lay
Foundations, are half bvilders all men say.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: My master forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O how does thy master? prithee commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: How's this? my master stays forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why let him stay, who hinders him forsooth?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The revel's ended now,
To visit you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am not sick.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I mean to see his chamber, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Am I his groom? where lay he last night, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: In the low matted parlour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There lies his way by the long gallery.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I mean your chamber: you're very merry mistress.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis a good sign I am sound hearted Jaques:
But if you'll know where I lie, follow me;
And what thou seest, deliver to thy master.

sp.speaker: Bja.
sp.l: Do gentle Jaques. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ha, is the wind in that door?
By'r lady we shall have foul weather then:
I do not like the shuffling of these women,
They are mad beasts when they knock their heads together:
I have observed them all this day; their whispers,
One in another's ear, their signs, and pinches,
And breaking often into violent laughters:
As if the end they purposed were their own.
Call you this weddings? Sure this is a knavery,
A very trick, and dainty knavery,
Marvellous finely carried, that's the comfort:
What would these women do in ways of honour,
That are such masters this way. Well, my sir
Has been as good at finding out these toys,
As any living; if he lose it now,
At his own peril be it. I must follow. Exit.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter servants with lights, Petruchio, Petronius, Moroso, Tranio, and Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You that are married, gentlemen, home at ye
For a round wager now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Of this night's stage?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I am your first man: a pair of gloves of twenty shillings.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Done: who takes me up next? I am for all bets.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Well lusty Laurence, were but my night now,
Old as I am, I would make you clap on spurs,
But I would reach you, and bring you to your trot too:
I would gallants.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well said good will; but where's the staff boy, ha?
Old father time, your hourglass is empty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A good tough train would break thee all to pieces;
Thou hast not breath enough to say thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Set how these boys despise us. Will you to bed son?
This pride will have a fall.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Upon your daughter;
But I shall rise again, if there be truth
In eggs, and buttered parsnips.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Will you to bed son, and leave talking;
Tomorrow morning we shall have you look,
For all your great words, like st. George at Kingston,
Running a footback from the furious dragon,
That with her angry tail belabours him
For being lazy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His courage quenched, and so far quenched —

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: 'Tis well sir.
What then?

sp.speaker: Saph.
sp.l: Fly, fly, quoth then the fearful dwarf;
Here is no place for living man.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Well my masters, if I do sink under my business, as I find 'tis very possible, I am not the first that has miscarried; so that's my comfort, what may be done without impeach or waste, I can and will do.
sp.l: How now is my fair bride a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: No truly sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.p: Not a-bed yet? body of me: we'll up and rifle her: here's a coil with a maidenhead, 'tis not entailed, is it?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: If it be, I'll try all the law i'th land, but I'll cut it off: let's up, let's up, come.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That you cannot neither.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Unless you'll drop through the chimney like a daw, or force a breach i'th windows: you may untile the house, 'tis possible.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: A moral sir, the ballad will express it:
The wind and the rain has turned you back again,
And you cannot be lodged there. The truth is all the doors
Are barricaded; not a cathole, but holds a murderer in't.
She's victualled for this month.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Art not thou drunk?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He's drunk, he's drunk; come, come, let's up.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am drunk: ye may go up, ye may gentlemen, but take heed to your heads: I say no more.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I'll try that. Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How dost thou say? the door fast locked fellow?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes truly sir, 'tis locked, and guarded too; and two as desperate tongues planted behind it, as ere yet battered: they stand upon their honours, and will not give up without strange composition, I'll assure you; marching away with their pieces cockted, and bullets in their mouths will not satisfy them.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How's this? how's this they are?
Is there another with her?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes marry is there, and an engineer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Who's that for heaven's sake?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Colonel Byancha, she commands the works: Spinala's but a ditcher to her, there's a half-moon; I am but a poor man, but if you'll give me leave, I'll venture a years wages, draw all your force before it, and mount your ablest piece of battery, you shall not enter it these three nights yet.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I should laugh at that good Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Beat back again, she's fortified for ever.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Am I drunk now sir?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He that dares most, go up now, and be cooled.
I have scaped a pretty scouring.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: What are they mad? have we another bedlam? They do not talk I hope?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: O terribly, extremely fearful, the noise at London-bridge is nothing near her.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How got she tongue?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: As you got tail, she was born to't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Locked out a doors, and on my wedding-night?
Nay, and I suffer this, I may go graze:
Come gentlemen, I'll batter; are these virtues?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do, and be beaten off with shame, as I was: I went up, came to th' door, knocked, nobody answered; knocked louder, yet heard nothing: would have broke in by force; when suddenly a waterwork flew from the window with such violence, that had I not ducked quickly like a friar, caetera quis nescit? The chamber's nothing but a mere Ostend, in every window pewter cannons mounted, you'll quickly find with what they are charged, sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why then tantara for us.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And all the lower works lined sure with small shot, long tongues with firelocks, that at twelve score blank hit to the heart: now and ye dare go up

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The window opens, beat a parley first;
I am so much amazed my very hair stands.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Why how now daughter: what intrenced?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little guarded for my safety sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For your safety sweetheart why who offends you?
I come not to use violence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think you cannot sir, I am better fortified.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I know your end,
You would fain reprieve your maidenhead
A night, or two.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, or ten, or twenty, or say an hundred;
Or indeed, till I list lie with you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: That's a shrewd saying; from this present hour,
I never will believe a silent woman.
When they break out they are bonfires.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Till you list lie with him? why who are you madam?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That trim gentleman's wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Cry you mercy, do you command too?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes marry does she, and in chief.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: I do command, and you shall go without:
(I mean your wife, for this night)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And for the next too wench, and so as't follows.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Thou wilt not, wilt 'A?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes indeed dear father,
And till he seal to what I shall set down,
For any thing I know, for ever.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Indeed these are bugs-words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You hear sir, she can talk, God be thanked.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I heard it not sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I find that all the pity bestowed upon this woman,
Makes but an anagram of an ill wife,
For she was never virtuous.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You'll let me in I hope, for all this jesting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hope still sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: You will come down I am sure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am sure I will not.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I'll fetch you then.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: The power of the whole county cannot sir,
Unless we please to yield, which yet I think
We shall not; charge when you please, you shall
Hear quickly from us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Bless me from a chicken of thy hatching,
Is this wiving?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prithee Maria tell me what's the reason,
And do it freely, you deal thus strangely with me?
You were not forced to marry, your consent
Went equally with mine, if not before it:
I hope you do not doubt I want that mettle
A man should have to keep a woman waking;
I would be sorry to be such a saint yet:
My person, as it is not excellent,
So 'tis not old, nor lame, nor weak with physic,
But well enough to please an honest woman,
That keeps her house, and loves her husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: My means and my conditions are no shamers
Of him that owes 'em, all the world knows that,
And my friends no reliers on my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All this I believe, and none of all these parcels
I dare except against; nay more, so far
I am from making these the ends I aim at,
These idle outward things, these women's fears,
That were I yet unmarried, free to choose
Through all the tribes of man, I'd take Petruchio
In's shirt, with one ten groats to pay the priest,
Before the best man living, or the ablest
That e'er leaped out of Lancashire, and they are right ones.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Why do you play the fool then, and stand prating
Out of the window like a broken miller!

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you will have me credit you Maria,
Come down, and let your love confirm it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there sir, that bargain's yet to make.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Play sure wench, the packs in thine own hand.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Let me die lousy, if these two wenches
Be not brewing knavery to stock a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why this is a riddle:
I love you, and I love you not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is so:
And till your own experience do untie it,
This distance I must keep.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you talk more,
I am angry, very angry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad on't, and I will talk.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prithee peace,
Let me not think thou art mad. I tell thee woman,
If thou goest forward, I am still Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I am worse, a woman that can fear
Neither Petruchio Furius, nor his fame,
Nor any thing that tends to our allegiance;
There's a short method for you, now you know me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you can carry't so, 'tis very well.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: No you shall carry it, sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Peace gentle Low-bel.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Use no more words, but come down instantly,
I charge thee by the duty of a child.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prithee come Maria, I forgive all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there; that duty, that you charge me by
(If you consider truly what you say)
Is now another man's, you gave't away
I'th church, if you remember, to my husband:
So all you can exact now, is no more
But only a due reverence to your person,
Which thus I pay: your blessing, and I am gone
To bed for this night.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This is monstrous:
That blessing that st. Dunstan gave the devil,
If I were near thee, I would give thee —
Pull thee down by th' nose.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Saints should not rave, sir;
A little rhubarb now were excellent.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Then by that duty you owe to me Maria,
Open the door, and be obedient: I am quiet yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do confess that duty; make your best on't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why give me leave, I will.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Sir, there's no learning
An old stiff jade to trot: you know the moral.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet as I take it sir, I owe no more
Than you owe back again.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You will not article?
All I owe, presently, let me but up, I'll pay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're too hot, and such prove jades at length;
You do confess a duty or respect to me from you again:
That's very near, or full the same with mine?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then by that duty, of respect, or what
You please to have it, go to bed and leave me,
And trouble me no longer with your fooling;
For know, I am not for you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well, what remedy?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A fine smart cudgel. O that I were near thee.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: If you had teeth now, what a case were we in?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: These are the most authentic rebels, next Tyrone, I ever read of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A week hence, or a fortnight, as you bear you,
And as I find my will observed, I may
With intercession of some friends be brought
May be to kiss you; and so quarterly
To pay a little rent by composition,
You understand me?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thou boy, thou.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Well there are more maids than Maudlin, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and more men than Michael.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I must not to bed with this stomach, and no meat lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Feed where you will, so it be sound, and wholesome,
Else live at livery, for I'll none with you.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: You had best back one of the dairy maids, they'll carry.
But take heed to your girths, you'll get a bruise else.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now if thou wouldst come down, and tender me:
All the delights due to a marriage bed,
Study such kisses as would melt a man,
And turn thyself into a thousand figures,
To add new flames unto me, I would stand
Thus heavy, thus regardless, thus despising
Thee, and thy best allurings: all thy beauty
That's laid upon your bodies, mark me well,
For without doubt your mind's are miserable,
You have no masks for them: all this rare beauty,
Lay but the painter, and the silk worm by,
The doctor with his diets, and the tailor,
And you appear like flayed cats, not so handsome.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And we appear like her that sent us hither,
That only excellent and beauteous nature;
Truly ourselves, for men to wonder at,
But too divine to handle; we are gold,
In our own natures pure; but, when we suffer
The husband's stamp upon us then alleys,
And bas ones of you, men are mingled with us,
And make us blush like copper.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Then, and never
Till then are women to be spoken of,
For till that time you have no souls I take it:
Good night: come gentlemen; I'll fast for this night,
But by this hand — well: I shall come up yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: There will I watch thee like a withered Jewry,
Thou shalt neither have meat, fire, nor candle,
Nor any thing that's easy: do you rebel so soon?
Yet take mercy.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Put up your pipes; to bed sir; I'll assure you
A month's siege will not shake us.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Well said colonel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bed to bed Petruchio: good night gentlemen,
You'll make my father sick with sitting up:
Here you shall find us any time these ten days,
Unless we may march off with our contentment.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I'll hang first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I'll quarter if I do not,
I'll make you know, and fear a wife Petruchio,
There my cause lies.
You have been famous for a woman tamer,
And bear the feared-name of a brave wife-breaker:
A woman now shall take those honours off,
And tame you; nay, never look so big, she shall believe me,
And I am she: what think ye; good night to all,
Ye shall find centines.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: If ye dare sally. Exeunt above.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: The devil's in 'em, e'en the very devil, the down right devil.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: I'll devil 'em: by these ten bones I will: I'll bring it to the old proverb no sport no pie: — taken down i'th top of all my speed; this is fine dancing: gentlemen, stick to me. You see our freehold's touched, and by this light, we will beleaguer' em, and either starve 'em out, or make 'em recreant.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I'll see all passages stopped, but those about 'em:
If the good women of the town dare succour 'em,
We shall have wars indeed.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I'll stand perdue upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: My regiment shall lie before.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I think so, 'tis grown too old to stand.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Let's in, and each provide his tackle,
We'll fire 'em out, or make 'em take their pardons,
Hear what I say, on their bare knees —
Am I Petruchio, feared, and spoken of,
And on my wedding night am I thus jaded? Exe. Omnes.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Rowland, and Pedro, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Now Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Very busy master Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What haste man?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I beseech you pardon me,
I am not mine own man.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou art not mad?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No; but believe me, as hasty —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: The cause good Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There be a thousand sir; you are not married?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Keep yourself quiet then.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You'll find a fiddle
That never will be tuned else: from all women —Exit. Enter Jaques,

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What ails the fellow trow? Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Your friend sir.
But very full of business.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Nothing but business?
Prithee the reason, is there any dying?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I would there were sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But thy business?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'll tell you in a word,
I am sent to lay
An imposition upon souse and puddings,
Pasties, and penny custards, that the women
May not relieve you rebels: fare ye well sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How does my mistress?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Like a resty jade.
She's spoiled for riding. Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What a devil ail they? Enter Sophocles.
Custards, and penny pasties, fools and fiddles,
What's this to'th purpose? O well met.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Now Rowland.
I cannot stay to talk long.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Here's stirring, but to what end? whether go you?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: To view the works.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What works?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: The women's trenches.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Trenches? are such to see?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I do not jest sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot understand you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Do not you hear
In what a state of quarrel the new bride
Stands with her husband?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let him stand with her, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: It should be, but by'r lady
She holds him out at pikes end, and defies him,
And now is fortified; such a regiment of rutters
Never defied men braver: I am sent
To view their preparation.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This is news
Stranger than arms in the air, you saw not
My gentle mistress?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, and meditating
Upon some secret business, when she had found it
She leapt for joy, and laughed, and straight retired
To shun Moroso.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This may be for me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Will you along?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Farewell. Exit Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell sir.
What should her musing mean, and what her joy in't,
If not for my advantage? stay ye; may notEnter Livia at one door, and Moroso at another harkening.
That bobtail jade Moroso, with his gold,
His gew-gauds, and the hope she has to send him
Quickly to dust, excite this? here she comes,
And yonder walks the stallion to discover:
Yet I'll salute her: save you beauteous mistress.

sp.speaker: Livi.
sp.l: The fox is kenneled for me: save you sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why do you look so strange?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I use to look sir
Without examination.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Twenty spur-royals for that word.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Belike then
The object discontents you?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes it does.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Is't come to this? you know me, do you not?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes as I may know many by repentance.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why do you break your faith?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I'll tell you that too,
You are under age, and no band holds upon you.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Sue out your understanding,
And get more hair, to cover your bare knuckle
(For boys were made for nothing, but dry kisses,)
And if you can, more manners.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Better still.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: And then if I want Spanish gloves, or stockings,
A ten-pound waistcoat, or a nag to hunt on,
It may be I shall grace you to accept 'em.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell, and when I credit women more,
May I to Smithfield, and there buy a jade,
(And know him to be so) that breaks my neck.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Because I have known you, I'll be thus kind to you;
Farewell, and be a man, and I'll provide you,
Because I see you're desperate, some staid chambermaid
That may relieve your youth, with wholesome doctrine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: She's mine from all the world: ha wench?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Ha chicken? —Gives him a box o'th ear and ex.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How's this? I do not love these favours: save you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: The devil take thee —Wrings him byth' nose.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There's a love token for you: thank me now.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I'll think on some of ye, and if I live,
My nose alone shall not be played withal. Exit.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: A box o'th ear do you say?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes sure a sound one,
Beside my nose blown to my hand; if Cupid
Shoot arrows of that weight, I'll swear devoutly,
Has sued his livery, and no more a boy.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You gave her some ill language?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Not a word,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Or might be you wear fumbling?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Would I had sir.
I had been a forehand then; but to be baffled,
And have no feeling of the cause —

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Be patient,
I have a medicine clapped to her back will cure her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No sure it must be afore sir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: On my conscience,
When I got these two wenches (Who till now
Ne'er showed their riding) I was drunk with bastard,
Whose nature is to form things like itself
Heady, and monstrous: did she slight him too?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That's all my comfort: a mere hobby-horse
She made child Rowland: 'sfoot she would not know him,
Not give him a free look, not reckon him
Among her thoughts, which I held more than wonder,
I having seen her within's three days kiss him
With such an appetite as though she would eat him.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: There is some trick in this: how did he take it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ready to cry; he ran away.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I fear her.
And yet I tell you, ever to my anger,
She is as tame as innocency; it may be
This blow was but a favour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I'll be sworn
'Twas well tied on then.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Go too, pray forget it,
I have bespoke a priest: and within's two hours
I'll have ye married; will that please you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I'll see it done myself, and give the lady
Such a sound exhortation for this knavery
I'll warrant you, shall make her smell this month on't,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay good sir, be not violent.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Neither —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: It may be
Out of her earnest love, there grew a longing
(As you know women have such toys) in kindness,
To give me a box o'th ear or so.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: It may be.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I reckon for the best still: this night than
I shall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You shall handsel her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Old as I am, I'll give her one blow for't
Shall make her groan this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Where's your jointure?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I have a jointure for her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Have your council
Perused it yet?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No council, but the night, and your sweet daughter
Shall ere peruse that jointure.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: I'll no demurrers on't nor no rejoinders.
The other's ready sealed.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Come then let's 'Comfort
My son Petruchio, he's like little children
That lose their babbles, crying ripe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Pray tell me,
Is this stern woman still upon the flaunt
Of bold defiance?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Still, and still she shall be
Till she be starved out: you shall see such justice,
That women shall be glad after this tempest
To tie their husband's shoes, and walk their horses;
That were a merry world: do you hear the rumour,
They say the women are in insurrection,
And mean to make a —

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: They'll sooner
Draw upon walls as we do: let 'em, let 'em,
We'll ship 'em out in cuck-stools, there they'll sail
As brave Columbus did, till they discover
The happy islands of obedience.
We stay too long, come.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Now saint George be with us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Now if I can but get in handsomely,
Father I shall deceive you, and this night
For all your private plotting, I'll no wedlock;
I have shifted sail, and find my sister's safety
A sure retirement; pray to heaven that Rowland
Do not believe too far, what I said to him,
For yon old foxcase forced me, that's my fear.
Stay, let me see, this quarter fierce Petruchio
Keeps with his Myrmidons: I must be sudden,
If he seize on me, I can look for nothing
But martial law; to this place have I scaped him;
Above there. Enter Maria, and Byancha above.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cheval'a.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Look out and know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor wench who sent thee,
What weak fool made thy tongue his orator?
I know you come to parley.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You're deceived,
Urged by the goodness of your cause I come
To do as you do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're too weak, too foolish,
To cheat us with your smoothness: do not we know
Thou hast been kept up tame?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Believe me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, prithee good Livia
Utter thy eloquence somewhere else.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Good cousin
Put up your pipes; we are not for your palate,
Alas we know who sent you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: On my word —

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Stay there; you must not think your word,
Or by your maidenhead, or such Sunday oaths
Sworn after even-song, can inveigle us
To lose our handfast: did their wisdoms think
That sent you hither, we would be so foolish,
To entertain our gentle sister Sinon,
And give her credit, while the wooden jade
Petruchio stole upon us: no good sister,
Go home, and tell the merry Greeks that sent you,
Ilium shall burn, and I, as did Aeneas,
Will on my back, spite of the Myrmidons,
Carry this warlike lady, and through seas
Unknown, and unbelieved, seek out a land,
Where like a race of noble Amazons,
We'll root ourselves and to our endless glory
Live, and despise base men.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I'll second ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: That's all one cousin.
I stand for freedom now.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Take heed of lying;
For by this light, if we do credit you,
And find you tripping, his infliction
That killed the prince of Orange, will be sport
To what we purpose.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Let me feel the heaviest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Swear by thy sweetheart Rowland (For by your maidenhead,
I fear 'twill be too late to swear) you mean
Nothing but fair and safe, and honourable
To us, and to yourself.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I swear.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Stay yet,
Swear as you hate Moroso, that's the surest,
And as you have a certain fear to find him
Worse than a poor dried Jack, full of more aches
Than autumn has; more knavery, and usury,
And foolery, and brokery, than dogs-ditch:
As you do constantly believe he's nothing
But an old empty bag with a grey beard,
And that beard such a bobtail, that it looks
Worse than a mare's tail eaten off with fillies:
As you acknowledge, that young handsome wench
That lies by such a bilbo blade, that bends
With every pass he makes to'th hilts, most miserable,
A dry nurse to his coughs, a fewterer
To such a nasty fellow, a robbed thing
Of all delights youth looks for: and to end,
One cast away on course beef, born to brush
That everlasting cassock that has worn
As many servants out, as the north-east passage
Has consumed sailors: if you swear this, and truly
Without the reservation of a gown
Or any meritorious petticoat,
'Tis like we shall believe you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I do swear it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay yet a little; came this wholesome motion
(Deal truly sister) from your own opinion,
Or some suggestion of the foe?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Never fear me,
For by that little faith I have in husbands,
And the great zeal I bear your cause, I come
Full of that liberty, you stand for, sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If we believe, and you prove recreant Livia,
Think what a maim you give the noble cause
We now stand up for: think what women shall
An hundred year hence speak thee, when examples
Are looked for, and so great ones, whose relations
Spoke as we do th'em wench, shall make new customs.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: If you be false, repent, go home, and pray,
And to the serious women of the city
Confess yourself; bring not a sin so heinous
To load thy soul, to this place: mark me Livia,
If thou be it double, and betrayest our honours,
And we fail in our purpose: get thee where
There is no women living, nor no hope
There ever shall be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If a mother's daughter,
That ever heard the name of stubborn husband
Found thee, and know thy sin.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nay, if old age,
One that has worn away the name of woman,
And no more left to know her by, but railing,
No teeth, nor eyes nor legs, but wooden ones
Come but i'th windward of thee, for sure she'll smell thee
Thou'lt be so rank, she'll ride thee like a nightmare,
And say her prayers backward to undo thee,
She'll curse thy meat and drink, and when thou marriest,
Clap a sound spell for ever on thy pleasures.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Children of five year old, like little fairies
Will pinch thee into motley, all that ever
Shall live, and hear of thee, I mean all women;
Will (Like so many furies) shake their keys,
And toss their flaming distaffs o'er their heads,
Crying revenge: take heed, 'tis hideous:
O 'tis a fearful office, if thou hadst
(Though thou beest perfect now) when thou cam'st, hither,
A false imagination, get thee gone,
And as my learned cousin said repent,
This place is sought by soundness.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So I seek it,
Or let me be a most despised example.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do believe thee, be thou worthy of it.
You come not empty?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: No, here's cakes, and cold meat,
And tripe of proof: behold here's wine, and beer,
Be sudden, I shall be surprised else.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Meet at the low parlour door, there lies a close way:
What fond obedience you have living in you,
Or duty to a man, before you enter,
Fling it away, 'twill but defile our offerings.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Be wary as you come,

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I warrant ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Mai.
sp.l: How goes your business girls?
A foot, and fair.
If fortune favour us: away to your strength
The country forces are arrived, be gone.
We are discovered else.
Arm? and be valiant.
Think of our cause.
Our justice.
'Tis sufficient. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Rowland and Tranio at several doors.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Now Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How do you?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How dost thou man,
Thou lookest ill:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes, pray can you tell me Tranio,
Who knew the devil first?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou hast heard I am sure of Esculapius.
So were they not well acquainted?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: May be so,
For they had certain dialogues together.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: He sold her fruit, I take it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, and cheese
That choked all mankind after.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Canst thou tell me
Whether that woman ever had a faith
After she had eaten?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's a school question

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No
'Tis no question, for believe me Tranio,
That cold fruit after eating bread naught in her
But windy promises, and colic vows
That broke out both ways.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou hast heard I am sure
Of Esculapius, a far famed surgeon,
One that could set together quartered traitors,
And make 'em honest men.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How dost thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let him but take, (If he dare do a cure
Shall get him fame indeed) a faithless woman,
There will be credit for him, that will speak him,
A broken woman Tranio, a base woman,
And if he can cure such a rack of honour
Let him come here, and practise.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Now for honour's sake
Why what ailest thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am ridden Tranio.
And spur-galled to the life of patience
(Heaven keep my wits together) by a thing
Our worst thoughts are too noble for, a woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Your mistress has a little frowned it may be?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She was my mistress.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is she not?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No Tranio.
She has done me such disgrace, so spitefully,
So like a woman bent to my undoing,
That henceforth a good horse shall be my mistress,
A good sword, or a book: and if you see her,
Tell her I do beseech you, even for love's sake. —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She may sooner
Count the good I have thought her,
Our old love and our friendship,
Shed one true tear, mean one hour constantly,
Be old, and honest, married, and a maid,
Then make me see her more, or more believe her:
And now I have met a messenger, farewell sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Alas poor Rowland, I will do it for thee:
This is that dog Moroso, but I hope
To see him cold i'th mouth first 'Ere he enjoy her:
I'll watch this young man, desperate thoughts may seize him,
And if my purse, or council can, I'll ease him.Exit

div.head: Scaena quinta.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Petronius, Moroso, and Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For look you gentlemen, say that I grant her
Out of my free and liberal love, a pardon,
Which you and all men else know she deserves not,
(Teneatis amici) can all the world leave laughing?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I think not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No by — they cannot;
For pray consider, have you ever read,
Or heard of, or can any man imagine.
So stiff a tomb boy, of so set a ma ice,
And such a brazen resolution,
As this young crabtree? and then answer me,
And mark but this too friends, without a cause,
Not a foul word comes cross her, not a fear,
She justly can take hold on, and do you think
I must sleep out my anger, and endure it,
Sow pillows to her ease, and lull her mischief?
Give me a spindle first: no, no my masters,
Were she as fair as Nell a Greece, and housewife,
As good as the wife sailor's wife, and young still,
Never above fifteen; and these tricks to it,
She should ride the wild mare once a week, she should.
(Believe me friends she should) I would tabor her,
Till all the legions that are crept into her,
Flew out with fire i'th tails.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Methinks you err now,
For to me seems, a little sufferance
Were a far surer cure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I can suffer,
Where I see promises of peace and amendment.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Give her a few conditions.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I'll be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Give her a crab-tree-cudgel.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: So I will;
And after it a flock-bed for her bones.
And hard eggs, till they brace her like a drum,
She shall be pampered with —
She shall not know a stool in ten months gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: This must not be. Enter Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq
sp.l: Arm, arm, out with your weapons,
For all the women in the kingdom's on ye;Enter Pedro.
They swarm like wasps, and nothing can destroy 'em,
But stopping of their hive, and smothering of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Stand to your guard sir, all the devils extant
Are broke upon us, like a cloud of thunder;
There are more women, marching hitherward,
In rescue of my mistress, than ere turned tail
At Sturbridge fair; and I believe, as fiery.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The forlorn-hope's led by a tanner's wife,
I know her by her hide; a desperate woman:
She flayed her husband in her youth, and made
Reins of his hide to ride the parish. Take 'em all together,
They are a genealogy of jennets, gotten
And born thus, by the boisterous breath of husbands;
They serve sure, and are swift to catch occasion,
(I mean their foes, or husbands) by the forelocks,
And there they hang like favours; cry they can,
But more for noble spite, than fear: and crying
Like the old giants that were foes to heaven,
They heave ye stool on stool, and fling main potlids
Like massy rocks, dart ladles, tossing irons,
And tongs like thunderbolts, till overlaid,
They fall beneath the weight; yet still aspiring
At those imperious godsheads, that would tame 'em.
There's ne'er a one of these, the worst and weakest,
(Choose where you will) but dare attempt the raising
Against the sovereign peace of Puritans,
A maypole, and a morris, maugre mainly
Their zeal, and dudgeon-daggers: and yet more,
Dares plant a stand of battering ale against 'em,
And drink 'em out o'th parish

sp.speaker: Saph.
sp.p: Lo you fierce Petruchio, this comes of your impatience.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There's one brought in the bears against the canons
Of the town, made it good, and fought 'em.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Another, to her everlasting fame, erected
Two alehouses of ease: the quarter-sessions
Running against her roundly; in which business
Two of the disannullers lost their nightcaps:
A third stood excommunicate by the cudgel.
The constable, to her eternal glory,
Drunk hard, and was converted, and she victor.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Then are they victualled with pies and puddings,
(The trappings of good stomachs) noble ale
The true defendor, sausages, and smoked ones,
If need be, such as serve for pikes; and pork,
(Better the Jews never hated:) here and there
A bottle of metheglin, a stout Bricaine
That will stand to 'em, what else they want, they war for.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Come to council,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Now you must grant conditions or the kingdom
Will have no other talk but this.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Away then, and let's advise the best.

sp.speaker: Soph:
sp.l: Why do you tremble?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Have I lived thus long to be knocked o'th head,
With half a washing beetle? pray be wise sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Come, something I'll do; but what it is I know not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: To council then, and let's avoid their follies.
Guard all the doors, or we shall not have a cloak left.Exe

div.stage: Enter three maids, at several doors.

sp.l: How goes the business, girls?
A foot, and fair.
If fortune favour us: away to your strength,
The country forces are arrived; be gone we are discovered else.
Arm, and be valiant.
Think of our cause.
Our justice.
'Tis sufficient.Exeunt

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, Petruchio, Moroso, Sophocles, and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I am indifferent, though I must confess,
I had rather see her carted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No more of that sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Are ye resolved to give her fair conditions?
'Twill be the safest way.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I am distracted,
Would I had run my head into a halter
When I first wooed her: if I offer peace,
She'll urge her own conditions, that's the devil.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why say she do?

sp.speaker: Petru:
sp.l: Say, I am made an ass, then;
I know her aim: may I with reputation
(Answer me this) with safety of mine honour,
(After the mighty manage of my first wife,
Which was indeed a fury to this filly,
After my twelve strong labours to reclaim her,
Which would have made don Hercules' horn mad,
And hid him in his hide) suffer this Sicily,
Ere she have warmed my sheets, ere grappled with me,
This pink, this painted foist, this cockle-boat,
To hang her fights out, and defy me friends,
A well known man of war? if this be equal,
And I may suffer, say, and I have done?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I do not think you may.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You'll make it worse sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray hear me good Petruchio: but e'en now,
You were contented to give all conditions,
To try how far she would carry: 'tis a folly,
(And you will find it so) to clap the curb on,
Ere you be sure it proves a natural wildness,
And not a forced. Give her conditions,
For on my life this trick is put into her.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I should believe so too.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And not her own.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You'll find it so.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then if she flounder with you,
Clap spurs on, and in this you'll deal with temperance,
Avoid the hurry of the world.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And looseMusic above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No honour on my life, sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I will do it.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: It seems they are very merry. Enter Jaques.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why God hold it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Now Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They are i'th flaunt, sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes we hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They have got a stick of fiddles, and they firk it
In wondrous ways, the two grand Capitanos,
(They brought the auxiliary regiments)
Dance with their coats tucked up to their bare breeches,
And bid them kiss 'em, that's the burden;
They have got metheglin, and audacious ale,
And talk like tyrants.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I peep't inSong!
At a loose lansket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A song, pray silence. All the women above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They look out.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Good even ladies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good you good even sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How have you slept tonight ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Exceeding well sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Did you not wish me with you?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: No, believe me,
I never thought upon you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Is that he?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She has drunk hard, mark her hood.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You are —

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Learnedly drunk, I'll hang else: let her utter.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And I must tell you, viva voce friend,
A very foolish fellow.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There's an ale figure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I thank you Susan Brotes.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Forward sister.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You have espoused here a hearty woman,
A comely, and courageous.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well I have so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And to the comfort of distressed damsels,
Women outworn in wedlock, and such vessels,
This woman has defied you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: It should seem so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: For thirteen causes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray by your patience mistress.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Forward sister.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Do you mean to treat of all these?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Who shall let her?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Do you hear, velvet-hood, we come not now
To hear your doctrine.

sp.speaker: Cunt.
sp.l: For the first, I take it,
It doth divide itself into seven branches.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Hark you good Maria,
Have you got a catechiser here?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Good zeal.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good three piled predication, will you peace,
And hear the cause we come for?

sp.speaker: Cunt.
sp.l: Yes bobtails
We know the cause you come for, here's the cause,
But never hope to carry her, never dream
Or flatter your opinions with a thought
Of base repentance in her.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Give me sack,
By this, and next strong ale.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Swear forward sister.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: By all that's cordial, in this place we'll bury
Our bones, fames, tongues, our triumphs; and than all
That ever yet was chronicled of woman;
But this brave wench, this excellent despiser,
This bane of dull obedience, shall inherit
His liberal will, and march off with conditions
Noble, and worth herself.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She shall Tom tilers,
And brave ones too; my hood shall make a hearse-cloth,
And I lie under it, like John o' Gaunt,
Ere I go less, my distaff stuck up by me,
For the eternal trophy of my conquests;
And loud fame at my head, with two main bottles,
Shall fill to all the world the glorious fall
Of old don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Yet a little further,
We have taken arms in rescue of this lady;
Most just and noble: if ye beat us off
Without conditions, and we recant,
Use us as we deserve; and first degrade us
Of all our ancient chambering: next that
The symbols of our secrecy, silk stockings,
Hew of our heels; our petticoats of arms
Tear of our bodies, and our bodkins break
Over our coward heads.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And ever after
To make the tainture most notorious,
At all our crests, videlicet our plackets.
Let laces hang, and we return again
Into our former titles, dairy maids.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No more wars: puissant ladies, show conditions,
And freely I accept 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Call in Livia;
She's in the treaty too. Enter Livia above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How, Livia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hear you that sir?
There's the conditions for ye, pray peruse 'em.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes, there she is: t'had been no right rebellion,
Had she held off; what think you man?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay nothing.
I have enough o'th prospect: o'my conscience,
The world's end, and the goodness of a woman
Will come together.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Are you there sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Cry you mercy sir, I saw you not: your blessing.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.p: Yes when I bless a jade, that stumbles with me. How are the articles?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: This is for you sir;
And I shall think upon't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You have used me finely.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: There's no other use of thee now extant,
But to be hung up; cassock, cap, and all,
For some strange monster at apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I hear you whore.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: It must be his then sir,
For need will then compel me.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Blessing on thee.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: He will undo me in mere pans of coals
To make him lusty.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: There's no talking to ''em;
How are they sir?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: As I expected: liberty and clothes,Reads.
When, and in what way she will: continual moneys,
Company, and all the house at her dispose;
No tongue to say, why is this? or whether will it;
New coaches, and some buildings, she appoints here,
Hangings, and hunting-horses: and for plate
And jewels for her private use, I take it,
Two thousand pound in present: then for music,
And women to read French;

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This must not be.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And at the latter end a clause put in,
That Livia shall by no man be importuned.
This whole month yet, to marry.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This is monstrous.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This shall be done, I'll humour her awhile:
If nothing but repentance, and undoing
Can win her love, I'll make a shift for one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: When ye are once a-bed , all these conditions
Lie under your own seal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.
And by that faith I gave you fore the priest
I'll ratify 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Stay, what pledges?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I'll take that oath;
But have a care you keep it.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: 'Tis not now
As when Andrea lived.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: If you do juggle,
Or alter but a letter or these articles
We have set down, the selfsame persecution.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mistrust him not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: By all my honesty —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enough I yield.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: What's this
Inserted here?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: That the two valiant women that command here
Shall have a supper made 'em, and a large one,
And liberal entertainment without grudging,
And pay for all their soldiers.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: That shall be too;
And if a tun of wine will serve to pay 'em,
They shall have justice: I ordain ye all
Paymasters, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then we shall have sport boys.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We'll meet you in the parlour.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Ne'er look sad sir, for I will do it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: There's no danger in't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For Livia's article, you shall observe it,
I have tied myself.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Along then: now
Either I break, or this stiff plant must bow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come, you shall take my counsel.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I shall hang first.
I'll no more love, that's certain, 'tis a bane,
(Next that they poison rats with) the most mortal:
No, I thank heaven, I have got my sleep again,
And now begin to write sense; I can walk ye
A long hour in my chamber like a man,
And think of something that may better me;
Some serious point of learning, or my state;
No more ay-mees, and miseries Tranio
Come near my brain. I'll tell thee, had the devil
But any essence in him of a man,
And could be brought to love, and love a woman,
'Twould make his head ache worser than his horns do;
And make him with a fire he never felt yet,
Would make him dance. I tell thee there is nothing
(It may be thy case Tranio, therefore hear me:)
Under the sun (Reckon the mass of follies
Crept into th'world with man) so desperate,
So mad, so senseless, poor and base, so wretched,
Roguy, and scurvy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Whether wilt thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: As 'tis to be in love.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And why for virtue's sake?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And why for virtue's sake? dost thou not conceive me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No by my troth.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Pray then, and heartily
For fear thou fall into 't: I'll tell thee why too,
(For I have hope to save thee) when thou lovest,
And first beginst to worship the gilt calf,
Imprimis, thou hast lost thy gentry,
And like a prentice flung away thy freedom.
Forthwith thou art a slave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's a new doctrine.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Next thou art no more man.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: A fippery;
Nothing but braided hair, and penny ribbon,
Glove, garter, ring, rose, or at best a swabber,
If thou canst love so near to keep thy making,
Yet thou wilt lose thy language.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: O Tranio,
Those things in love, ne'er talk as we do,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No without doubt, they sigh and shake the head,
And sometimes whistle dolefully.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No tongue?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes Tranio, but no truth in't, nor no reason,
And when they cant (For 'tis a kind of canting)
Ye shall hear, if you reach to understand 'em
(Which you must be a fool first, or you cannot)
Such gibberish; such believe me, I protest sweet,
And o dear heavens, in which such constellations
Reign at the births of lovers, this is too well,
And deign me lady, deign me I beseech ye
You poor unworthy lump, and then she licks him

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.l: A — on't, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thun hast hit it:
Then talks she ten times worse, and wries and wriggles,
As though she had the itch (And so it may be.)

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why thou art grown a strange discoverer.

sp.speaker: Row
sp.l: Of mine own follies Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Wilt thou Rowland,
Certain ne'er love again?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I think so, certain,
And if I be not dead drunk, I shall keep it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tell me but this; what dost thou think of women?

sp.speaker: Row
sp.l: Why as I think of fiddles, they delight me,
Till their strings break.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What strings?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Their modesties,
Faithes, vows and maidenheads, for they are like kits
They have but four strings to 'em.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What wilt thou
Give me for ten pound now, when thou next lovest,
And the same woman still?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Give me the money;
A hundred, and my bond for't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But pray hear me.
I'll work all means I can to reconcile ye:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Do, do, give me the money.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Work Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You shall go sometimes where she is.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes straight.
This is the first good I ere got by woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You would think it strange now, if another beauty
As good as hers, say better.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Conceive me,
This is no point o'th wager.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Love you as much, or more, than she now hates you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing, let 'em love: ten pound more,
I never love that woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There it is;
And so an hundred, if you lose.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: 'Tis done;
Have you another to put in?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, no sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am very sorry: now will I erect
A new game and go hate for th' bell, I am sure
I am in excellent case to win.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I must have leave.
To tell you, and tell truth too, what she is,
And how she suffers for you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Ten pound more,
I never believe you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No sir, I am stinted.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well, take your best way then.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let's walk, I am glad
Your sullen fever's off.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Shalt see me Tranio
A monstrous merry man now: let's to the wedding,
And as we go, tell me the general hurry
Of these mad wenches, and their works.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And do thy worst.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.l: Something I'll do.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Do Tranio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A pair of stocks bestride 'em, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes they are gone; and all the pans i'th town
Beating before 'em: what strange admonitions
They gave my master, and how fearfully
They threatened, if he broke 'em?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: On my conscience
Has found his full match now.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That I believe too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How did she entertain him?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: She looked on him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But scurvily.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: With no great affection
That I saw: and I heard some say he kissed her,
But 'twas upon a treaty, and some copies
Say but her cheek.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Jaques, what wouldst thou give
For such a wife now?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Full as many prayers
As the most zealous Puritan conceives
Out of the meditation of fat veal,
Or birds of prey, crammed capons, against players,
And to as good a tune too, but against her:
That heaven would bless me from her: mark it Pedro,
If this house be not turned within this fortnight
With the foundation upward, I'll be carted.
My comfort is yet that those amorities,
That came to back her cause, those heathen whores had
Their hoods hallowed with sack.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How devilish drunk they were?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And how they tumbled, Pedro, didst thou mark
The country cavaliero?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Out upon her,
How she turned down the bagget?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I that sunk her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That drink was well put to her; what a sober salt
When the chair fell, she fetched, with her heels upward?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And what a piece of landscape she discovered?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Didst mark her, when her hood fell in the posset?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes, and there rid, like a Dutch hoy; the tumbril,
When she had got her ballast.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That I saw too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: How fain she would have drawn on Sophocles
To come aboard, and how she simpered it —

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I warrant her, she has been a worthy striker.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I'th heat of summer there had been some hope on't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hang her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: She offered him a harry-groat, and belched out,
Her stomach being blown with ale, such courtship,
Upon my life has given him twenty stools since:
Believe my calculation, these old women
When they are tippled, and a little heated
Are like new wheels, they'll roar you all the town o'er
Till they be greased.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The city cinquepace
Dame toss and butter, had he bob too?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes,
But she was sullen drunk, and given to filching,
I see her offer at a spoon; my master
I do not like his look, I fear has fasted
For all this preparation; let's steal by him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Not let you touch her all this night?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Not touch her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Where was your courage?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Where was her obedience?
Never poor man was shamed so; never rascal
That keeps a stud of whores was used so basely.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray you tell me one thing truly;
Do you love her?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I did not, upon that condition
I passed thee half my land.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: It may be then,
Her modesty required a little violence?
Some women love to struggle.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She had it,
And so much that I sweat for't, so I did,
But to no end: I washed an Aethiop;
She swore my force might weary her, but win her
I never could, nor should, till she consented;
And I might take her body prisoner,
But for her mind or appetite —

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: 'Tis strange;
This woman is the first I ever read of,
Refused a warranted occasion,
And standing on so fair terms.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I shall quit her.

sp.speaker: Soph,
sp.l: Used you no more art?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I swore to her,
And by no little ones, if presently
Without more disputation on the matter,
She grew not nearer to me, and dispatched me
Out of the pain I was, for I was nettled,
And willingly, and eagerly, and sweetly,
I would to her chambermaid, and in her hearing
Begin her such a hunts-up.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then she started?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No more than I do now; many she answered
If I were so disposed, she could not help it;
But there was one called Jaques, a poor butler
One that might well content a single woman.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And he should tilt her.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: To that sense, and last
She bade me yet these six nights look for nothing,
Nor strive to purchase it, but fair good night,
And so good morrow, and a kiss or two
To close my stomach, for her vow had sealed it,
And she would keep it constant.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Stay ye, stay ye,
Was she thus when you wooed her?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Nothing Sophocles,
More keenly eager, I was oft afraid
She had been light, and easy, she would shower
Her kisses so upon me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then I fear
Another spoke's i'th wheel.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now thou hast found me,
There gnaws my devil, Sophocles, oh patience
Preserve me; that I make her not example
By some unworthy way; as flaying her,
Boiling, or making verjuce, drying her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I hear her.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Mark her then, and see the heir
Of spite and prodigality, she has studied
A way to beggar's both, and by this handMaria at the door, and servant and woman.
She shall be if I live a doxy.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Fie sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do not like that dressing, 'tis too poor,
Let me have six gold laces, broad and massy.
And betwixt every lace a rich embroidery,
Line the gown through with plush, perfumed, and purfle
All the sleeves down with pearl.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What think you Sophocles.
In what point stands my state now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For those hangings
Let 'em be carried where I gave appointment,
They are too base for my use, and bespeak
New pieces of the civil wars of France,
Let 'em be large and lively, and all silk work,
The borders gold.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I marry sir, this cuts it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That fourteen yards of satin give my woman,
I do not like the colour, 'tis too civil:
There's too much silk i'th lace too; tell the Dutchman
That brought the mares, he must with all speed send me
Another suit of horses, and by all means
Ten calf of hawks for th' river, I much care not
What price they bear, so they be sound, and flying,
For the next winter, I am for the country;
And mean to take my pleasure; where's the horse man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She means to ride a great horse.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: With a side saddle?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, and she'll run a tilt within this twelvemonth
