sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tomorrow I'll begin to learn, but pray sir
Have a great care he be an easy doer,
'Twill spoil a scholar else.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: An easy doer,
Did you hear that?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I shall meet her morals
Ere it be long I fear not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O good morrow.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good morrow lady, how is't now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Faith sickly,
This house stands in an ill air.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yet more charges?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Subject to rots, and rheums; out on't, 'tis nothing
But a tilled fog.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What think of the lodge then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like the seat, but 'tis too little, Sophocles
Let me have thy opinion, thou hast judgement.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What if I pluck it down,
And built a square upon it, with two courts
Still rising from the entrance?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And i'th midst
A college for young scolds.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And to the southward
Take in a garden of some twenty acres,
And cast it off the Italian fashion, hanging.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And you could cast yourself so too; pray lady
Will not this cost much money?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Some five thousand,
Say six: I'll have it battled too.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And gilt; Maria,
This is a fearful course you take pray think on't,
You are a woman now, a wife, and his
That must in honesty, and justice look for
Some due obedience from you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That bare word
Shall cost you many a pound more, build upon't;
Tell me of due obedience? what's a husband?
What are we married for, to carry sumpters?
Are we not one piece with you, and as worthy
Our own intentions, as you yours?

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Pray hear me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take two small drops of water, equal weighed,
Tell me which is the heaviest, and which ought
First to descend in duty?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You mistake me;
I urge not service from you, nor obedience
In way of duty, but of love, and credit;
All I expect is but a noble care
Of what I have brought you, and of what I am,
And what our name may be

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's in my making.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: 'Tis true it is so.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Yes it is Petruchio,
For there was never man without our moulding,
Without our stamp upon him, and our justice,
Left any thing three ages after him
Good, and his own.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good lady understand him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do too much, sweet Sophocles, he's one
Of a most spiteful self condition,
Never at peace with any thing but age,
That has no teeth left to return his anger:
A bravery dwells in his blood yet, of abusing
His first good wife; he's sooner fire than powder,
And sooner mischief.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If I be so sudden
Do not you fear me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No nor yet care for you,
And if it may be lawful, I defy you:

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Does this become you now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It shall become me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou disobedient, weak, vainglorious woman,
Were I but half so wilful, as thou spightful,
I should now drag thee to thy duty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Drag me?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: But I am friends again: take all your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now you perceive him Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I love thee
Above thy vanity, thou faithless creature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I had been so happy when I married,
But to have met an honest man like thee,
For I am sure thou art good, I know thou art honest,
A handsome hurtless man, a loving man,
Though never a penny with him; and those eyes,
That face, and that true heart; wear this for my sake,
And when thou thinkst upon me pity me:
I am cast away,Exit Mar.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why how now man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray leave me,
And follow your advices.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: The man's jealous:

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I shall find a time ere it be long, to ask you
One or two foolish questions.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I shall answer
As well as I am able, when you call me:
If she mean true, 'tis but a little killing,
And if I do not venture its —
Farewell sir. Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray farewell. Is there no keeping
A wife to one man's use? no wintering
These cattle without straying? 'tis hard dealing,
Very hard dealing, gentlemen, strange dealing:
Now in the name of madness, what star reigned,
What dog-star, bull, or bear-star, when I married
This second wife, this whirlwind, that takes all
Within her compass? was I not well warned,
(I thought I had, and I believe I know it,)
And beaten to repentance in the days
Of my first doting? had I not wife enough
To turn my love too? did I want vexation,
Or any special care to kill my heart?
Had I not every morning a rare breakfast,
Mixed with a learned lecture of ill language,
Louder than Tom of Lincoln; and at dinner,
A diet of the same dish? was there evening
That ere past over us, without thou knave,
Or thou whore, for digestion? had I ever
A pull at this same poor sport men run mad for,
But like a cur I was fain to show my teeth first,
And almost worry her? and did heaven forgive me,
And take this serpent from me? and am I
Keeping tame devils now again? my heart aches;
Something I must do speedily: I'll die,
If I can handsomely, for that's the way
To make a rascal of her; I am sick,
And I'll go very near it, but I'll perish. Exit.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Livia, Byancha, Tranio, and Rowland.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then I must be content sir, with my fortune.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And I with mine.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I did not think, a look,
Or a poor word or two, could have displanted
Such a fixed constancy, and for your end too.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come, come, I know your courses: there's no gewgaws,
Your rings, and bracelets, and the purse you gave me,
The money's spent in entertaining you
At plays, and cherry-gardens.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: There's your chain too.
But if you'll give me leave, I'll wear the hair still;
I would yet remember you.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Give him his love wench;
The young man has employment for 't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Fie Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: You cannot fie me out a hundred pound
With this poor plot: yet, let me ne'er see day more,
If something do not struggle strangely in me.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Young man, let me talk with you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well young woman.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: This was your mistress once.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Are ye honest?
I see you are young, and handsome.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am honest.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Why that's well said: and there's no doubt your judgement
Is good enough, and strong enough to tell you
Who are your foes, and friends: why did you leave her?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She made a puppy of me.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Be that granted:
She must do so sometimes, and oftentimes;
Love were too serious else.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: A witty woman.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Had you loved me —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I would I had.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: And dear;
And I had loved you so: you may love worse sir,
But that is not material.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I shall lose.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Some time or other for variety
I should have called you fool, or boy, or bid you
Play with the pages: but have loved you still,
Out of all question, and extremely too;
You are a man made to be loved:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This woman
Either abuses me, or loves me deadly.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: I'll tell you one thing, if I were to choose
A husband to mine own mind, I should think
One of your mother's making would content me,
For of my conscience she makes good ones.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Lady,
I'll leave you to your commendations:
I am in again, the devil take their tongues.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You shall not go.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I will: yet thus far Livia,
Your sorrow may induce me to forgive you,
But never love again; if I stay longer,
I have lost two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good sir, but thus much —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Turn if thou beest a man.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: But one kiss of you;
One parting kiss, and I am gone too.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come,
I shall kiss fifty pound away at this clap:
We'll have one more, and then farewell.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, thou bearest a kind heart with thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Has made a stand.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: A noble, brave young fellow,
Worthy a wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I will: I will not. Exit Rowland.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He's gone: but shot again; play you but your part,
And I will keep my promise: forty angels
In fair gold lady: wipe your eyes: he's yours
If I have any wit.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I'll pay the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Come then, let's see your sister, how she fares now,
After her skirmish: and be sure, Moroso
Be kept in good hand; then all's perfect, Livia.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques, what becomes of us?
O my sweet master.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Run for a physician,
And a whole peck of pothecaries, Pedro.
He will die, diddle, diddle die: if they come not quickly,
And bring all people that are skilful
In lungs and livers: raise the neighbours,
And all the aquavite-bottles extant;
And, oh the parson, Pedro; oh the parson,
A little of his comfort, never so little;
Twenty to one you find him at the bush,
There's the best ale.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I fly. Exit Pedro.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out with the trunks, ho:
Why are you idle? Sirrah, up to th'chamber,
And take the hangings down, and see the linen
Packed up, and sent away within this half hour.
What are the carts come yet? some honest body
Help down the chests of plate, and some the wardrobe,
Alas we are undone else.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Pray forsooth,
And I beseech ye, tell me, is he dead yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, but is drawing on: out with the armour.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Then I'll go see him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art undone then fellow: no man that has
Been near him come near me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why how now lady, what means this?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now daughter, how dos my son?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Save all you can for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Be of good comfort sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my casket.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How does thy husband woman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Get you gone, if you mean to save your lives: the sickness.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Stand further off, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is i'th house sir,
My husband has it now;
Alas he is infected, and raves extremely:
Give me some counsel friends.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Why lock the doors up,
And send him in a woman to attend him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have bespoke two women; and the city
Hath sent a watch by this time: meat nor money
He shall not want, nor prayers.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How long is't
Since it first took him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But within this three hours. Enter watch.
I am frighted from my wits: — oh here's the watch;
Pray do your office, lock the doors up friends,
And patience be his angel.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: This comes unlooked for:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll to the lodge; some that are kind and love me,
I know will visit me. Petruchio within.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Do you hear my masters: ho, you that lock the doors up.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: 'Tis his voice.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hold, and let's hear him.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Will ye starve me here: am I a traitor, or an heretic.
Or am I grown infectious?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Pray sir, pray.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I am as well as you are, goodman puppy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray have patience,
You shall want nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I want a cudgel,
And thee, thou wickedness.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: He speaks well enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Had ever a strong heart sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Will ye hear me?
First be pleased
To think I know ye all, and can distinguish
Every man's several voice: you that spoke first,
I know my father in law; the other Tranio,
And I heard Sophocles; the last, pray mark me,
Is my damned wife Maria:
If any man misdoubt me for infected,
There is mine arm, let any man look on't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Save ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Petron:
sp.l: O welcome doctor,
Ye come in happy time; pray your opinion,
What think you of his pulse?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: It beats with busiest,
And shows a general inflammation,
Which is the symptom of a pestilent fever,
Take twenty ounces from him.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Take a fool;
Take an ounce from mine arm, and doctor deuce-ace,
I'll make a close-stool of your velvet Costard.
— gentlemen, do ye make a may-game on me?
I tell ye once again, I am as sound,
As well, as wholesome, and as sensible,
As any of ye all: let me out quickly,
Or as I am a man, I'll beat the walls down,
And the first thing I light upon shall pay for't.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Nay we'll go with you doctor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis the safest;
I saw the tokens sir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Then there is but one way.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Will it please you open?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His fit grows stronger still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let's save ourselves sir,
He's passed all worldly cure.
Friend's do your office.
And what he wants, if money, love, or labour,
Or any way may win it, let him have it.
Farewell, and pray my honest friends —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why rascals,
Friends, gentlemen, thou beastly wife, Jaques;
None hear me? who at the door there?

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.l: Think I pray sir,
Whether you are going, and prepare yourself.

sp.speaker: 2 watch
sp.l: These idle thoughts disturb you, the good gentlewoman
Your wife has taken care you shall want nothing.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Shall I come out in quiet? answer me,
Or shall I charge a fowling-piece, and make
Mine own way; two of ye I cannot miss,
If I miss three; ye come here to assault me.
I am as excellent well, I thank heaven for't,
And have as good a stomach at this instant —

sp.speaker: 2 watch
sp.l: That's an ill sign.

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.l: He draws on; he's a dead man,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And sleep as soundly; will ye look upon me?

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.l: Do you want pen and ink? while you have sense sir,
Settle your state.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Sirs, I am well, as you are;
Or any rascal living.

sp.speaker: 2 watch
sp.l: Would you were sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Look to yourselves, and if you love your lives,
Open the door, and fly me, for I shoot else;
— I'll shoot, and presently, chain-bullets;
And under four I will not kill.

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.l: Let's quit him,
It may be it is trick: he's dangerous.

sp.speaker: 2 watch
sp.p: The devil take the hindmost, I cry. Exit watch running.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Have among ye;
The door shall open too, I'll have a fair shoot;
Are ye all gone? tricks in my old days, crackers
Put now upon me? and by lady green-sleeves?
Am I grown so tame after all my triumphs?
But that I should be thought mad, if I railed
As much as they deserve against these women,
I would now rip up from the primitive cuckold,
All their arch-villanies, and all their dobles,
Which are more than a hunted hare ere thought on:
When a man has the fairest, and the sweetest
Of all their sex, and as he thinks the noblest,
What has he then? and I'll speak modestly,
He has a quartern-ague, that shall shake
All his estate to nothing; never cured,
Nor never dying; has a sip to venture
His fame, and credit in, which if he man not
With more continual labour then a galley
To make her tith, either she grows a tumbril
Not worth the cloth she wears; or springs more leaks
Than all the fame of his posterity
Can ever stop again: I could rail twenty days;
Out on 'em hedgehogs,
He that shall touch 'em, has a thousand thorns
Runs through his fingers: if I were unmarried,
I would do any thing below repentance,
Any base dunhill slavery; be a hangman,
Ere I would be a husband: oh the thousand,
Thousand, ten thousand ways they have to kill us!
Some fall with too much stringing of the fiddles,
And those are fools; some, that they are not suffered,
And those are maudlin-lovers: some, like scorpions,
They poison with their tails, and those are martyrs;
Some die with doing good, those benefactors,
And leave 'em land to leap away: some few,
For those are rarest, they are said to kill
With kindness, and fair usage; but what they are
My catalogue discovers not: only 'tis thought
They are buried in old walls with their heels upward.
I could rail twenty days together now.
I'll seek 'em out, and if I have not reason,
And very sensible, why this was done,
I'll go a birding yet, and some shall smart for't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That I do love her, is without all question,
And most extremely, dear, most exactly;
And that I would e'en now, this present Monday,
Before all others, maids, wives, women, widows,
Of what degree or calling, marry her,
As certain too; but to be made a whim-wham,
A jib-crack, and a gentleman o'th first house
For all my kindness to her.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How you take it?
Thou get a wench, thou get dozen nightcaps;
Wouldst have her come, and lick thee like a calf,
And blow thy nose, and buss thee?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Not so neither.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have her do?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Do as she should do;
Put on a clean smock, and to church, and marry,
And then to bed a god's name, this is fair play,
And keeps the King's peace; let her leave her bobs,
I have had too many of them, and her quillets,
She is as nimble that way as an eel;
But in the way she ought to me especially,
A sow of lead is swifter.

sp.speaker: Petron
sp.l: Quote your griefs down.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Give fair quarter, I am old and crazy,
And subject to much fumbling, I confess it;
Yet something I would have that's warm, to hatch me:
But understand me I would have it so,
I buy not more repentance in the bargain
Then the ware's worth I have; if you allow me
Worthy your son-in-law, and your allowance,
Do it a way of credit; let me show so,
And not be troubled in my visitations,
With blows, and bitterness, and down right railings,
As if we were to couple like two cats,
With clawing, add loud clamour:

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Thou fond man
Hast thou forgotten the Ballard, crabbed age,
Can may and January match together,
And never a storm between 'em? say she abuse thee,
Put case she do.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Nay, believe she does.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I do believe she does.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: And devilishly:
Art thou a whit the worse?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That's not the matter,
I know, being old, 'tis fit I am abused;
I know 'tis handsome, and I know moreover
I am to love her for't.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now you come to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay more than this; I find too, and find certain,
What gold I have, pearl, bracelets, rings, or ouches,
Or what she can desire, gowns, petticoats,
Waistcoats, embroidered-stockings, scarffs, calls, feathers
Hats, five pound garters, muffs, masks, ruffs, and ribbons,
I am to give her for't.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: 'Tis right, you are so.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: But when I have done all this, and think it duty,
Is't requisite another bore my nostrils?
Riddle me that.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Go get you gone, and dream
She's thine within these two days, for she is so;
The boy's beside the saddle: get warm broths,
And feed apace; think not of worldly business,
It cools the blood; leave off your tricks, they are hateful,
And mere forerunners of the ancient measures;
Contrive your beard o'th top cut like verdugoes;
It shows you would be wise, and burn your nightcap,
It looks like half a winding-sheet, and urges
From a young wench nothing but cold repentance:
You may eat onions, so you'll not be lavish.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: They purge the blood, and quicken,
But after 'em, conceive me, sweep your mouth,
And where there wants a tooth, stick in a clove.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I hope once again, say't,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You shall sir:
And you shall have your hope. Enter Byancha and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Why there's a match then.

sp.speaker: Byan.
sp.l: You shall not find me wanting, get you gone.
Here's the old man, he'll think you are plotting else
Something against his new son. Exit Tranio.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Fare ye well sir. Exit Moroso.

sp.speaker: Byan.
sp.l: And every buck had his doe,
And every cuckold a bell at his toe:
O what sport should we have then, than bays then,
Oh what sport should we have then?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: This is the spirit, that inspires 'em all.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Give you good e'en.

sp.speaker: Petro
sp.l: A word with you sweet lady.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I am very hasty sir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: So you were ever.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Well what's your will?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Was not your skilful hand
In this last stratagem? were not your mischiefs
Eking the matter on?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: In's shutting up?
Is that it?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Do,

sp.speaker: By
sp.l: And truly.
Good old man, I do grieve exceeding much,
I fear too much.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I am sorry for your heaviness.
Belike you can repent then?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: There you are wide too.
Not that the thing was done (Conceive me rightly)
Does any way molest me.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: What then lady?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: But that I was not in't, there's my sorrow, there
Now you understand me, for I'll tell you,
It was so sound a piece, and so well carried,
And if you mark the way, so handsomely,
Of such a height, and excellence, and art
I have not known a braver, for conceive me,
When the gross fool her husband would be sick —

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Pray stay.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nay, good, your patience: and no sense for't,
Then stepped your daughter in.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: By your appointment.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I would it had, on that condition
I had but one half smock, I like it so well;
And like an excellent cunning woman, cured me
One madness with another, which was rare,
And to our weak beliefs, a wonder.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Hang ye,
For surely, if your husband look not to ye,
I know what will.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I humbly thank your worship.
And so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You have a hand I hear too.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I have two sir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: In my young daughter's business.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: You will find there
A fitter hand than mine, to reach her frets,
And play down diddle to her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I shall watch ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: And I shall have justice.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: That's all one;
I shall be with you at a turn hence forward.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Get you a posset too; and so good even sir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And as I told your worship, all the hangings,
Brass, pewter, plate, e'en to the very looking-glasses.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And that that hung for our defence, the armour,
And the march beer was going too: o Jaques
What a sad sight was that?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Even the two roundlets,
The two that was our hope, of muskadel,
(Better never tongue tripped over) these two cannons,
To batter brawn withal at Christmas, sir
E'en those two lovely twins, the enemy
Had almost cut off clean.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Go trim the house up.
And put the things in order as they were. Exit Ped. and Jaq.
I shall find time for all this: could I find her
But constant any way, I had done my business;
Were she a whore directly, or a scold,
An unthrift, or a woman made to hate me,
I had my wish, and knew which way to rain her:
But while she shows all these, and all their losses,
A kind of linsey woolsey, mingled mischief
Not to be guessed at, and whether true, or borrowed,
Not certain neither, what a hap had I,Enter Maria.
And what a tidy fortune, when my fate
Flung me upon this bear-whelp? here she comes
Now if she have a colour, for the fault is
A cleanly one, upon my conscience
I shall forgive her yet, and find a something
Certain, I married for: her wit: I'll mark her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not let his wife come near him in his sickness,
Not come to comfort him? she that all laws
Of heaven, and nations have ordained his second,
Is she refused? and two old paradoxes,
Pieces of five and fifty, without faith
Clapped in upon him? has a little pet,
That all young wives must follow necessary
Having their maidenheads —

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This is an axiom
I never heard before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Or say rebellion
If we durst be so foul, which two fair words
Alas win us from, in an hour, an instant,
We are so easy, make him so forgetful
Both of his reason, honesty, and credit,
As to deny his wife a visitation?
His wife, that (Though she was a little foolish,)
Loved him, o heaven forgive her for't! nay doted,
Nay had run mad, had she not married him,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Though I do know this falser than the devil,
I cannot choose but love it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What do I know
But those that came to keep him, might have killed him,
In what a case had I been then? I dare not
Believe him such a base, debauched companion,
That one refusal of a tender maid
Would make him feign this sickness out of need,
And take a keeper to him of fourscore
To play at billiards; one that mewed content
And all her teeth together; not come near him?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This woman would have made a most rare Jesuit
She can prevaricate on any thing:
There was not to be thought a way to save her
In all imagination, beside this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His unkind dealing, which was, worst of all,
In sending, who knows whither, all the plate,
And all the householdstuff, had I not crossed it,
By a great providence, and my friend's assistance
Which he will thank me one day for: alas,
I could have watched as well as they, have served him
In any use, better, and willinger.
The law commands me to do it, love commands me.
And my own duty charges me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Heaven bless me.
And now I have said my prayers, I'll go to her:
Are you a wife for any man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For you sir.
If I were worse, I were better; that you are well,
At least, that you appear so, I thank heaven,
Long may it hold and that you are here, I am glad too,
But that you have abused me wretchedly,
And such a way that shames the name of husband,
Such a malicious mangy way, so mingled,
(Never look strangely on me, I dare tell you)
With breach of honesty, care, kindness, manners.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Holla, you kick too fast.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Was I a stranger?
Or had I vowed perdition to your person?
Am I not married to you, tell me that?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I could not tell you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is my presence,
The stock I come of, which is worshipful,
If I should say right worshipful, I lied not,
My grandsire was a knight.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: O'the shire?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A soldier,
Which none of all thy family e'er heard off,
But one conductor of thy name, a grazier
That ran away with pay: or am I grown
(Because I have been a little peevish to you,
Only to try your temper) such a dog-latch
I could not be admitted to your presence?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If I endure this, hang me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And two deaths heads,
Two Harry groats, that had their faces worn,
Almost their names away too.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now hear me.
For I will stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This you shall:
However you shall think to flatter me,
For this offence, which no submission.
Can ever mediate for, you'll find it so,
Whatever you shall do by intercession,
What you can offer, what your land can purchase,
What all your friends, or families can win,
Shall be but this, not to forswear your knowledge,
But ever to forbear it: now your will sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou art the subtlest woman I think living,
I am sure the lewdest; now be still, and mark me;
Were I but any way addicted to the devil,
I should now think I had met a playfellow
To profit by, and that way the most learned
That ever taught to murmur. Tell me thou,
Thou most poor, paltry spiteful whore: do you cry?
I'll make you roar, before I leave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Was it not sin enough, thou fruiterer
Full of the fall thou eatest: thou devil's broker,
Thou seminary of all sedition,
Thou sword of vengeance, with a thread hung o'er us,
Was it not sin enough, and wickedness
In full abundance? was it not vexation
At all points, cap a poe? nay, I shall pinch you,
Thus like a rotten rascal to abuse.
The name of heaven, the tie of marriage,
The honour of thy friends; the expectation
Of all that thought thee virtuous, with rebellion,
Childish and base rebellion, but continuing.
After forgiveness too, and worse, your mischief,
And against him setting the hope of heaven by,
And the dear reservation of his honour
Nothing above ground could have won to hate thee:
Well go thy ways.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You shall hear me out first:
What punishment mayest thou deserve, thou thing,
Thou idle thing of nothing, thou pulled primrose,
That two hours after, art a weed, and withered,
For this last flourish on me? am I one
Selected out of all the husbands living,
To be so ridden by a tit of ten pence,
Am I so blind and bedrid? I was mad,
And had the plague, and no man must come near me,
I must be shut up, and my substance bezeled,
And an old woman watch me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well sir, well,
You may well glory in't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And when it comes to opening, 'tis my plot,
I must undo myself forsooth: dost hear me?
If I should beat thee now, as much may be,
Dost thou not well deserve it, of thy conscience,
Dost thou not cry, come beat me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I defy you.
And my last loving tears farewell: the first stroke,
The very first you give me if you dare strike,
Try me, and you shall find it so, for ever
Never to be recalled: I know you love me,
Mad till you have enjoyed me; I do turn
Utterly from you, and what man I meet first,
That has but spirit to deserve a favour,
Let him bear any shape, the worse the better,
Shall kill you, and enjoy me; what I have said
About your foolish sickness, ere you have me
As you would have me, you shall swear, is certain,
And challenge any man, that dares deny it;
And in all companies approve my actions,
And so farewell for this time. Exit Mar.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Grief go with thee,
If there be any witchcrafts, herbs, or potions,
Saying my prayers backward, fiends, or fairies
That can again unlove me, I am made. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mistress, you must do it.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Are the writings ready I told you of?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes they are ready, but to what use I know not.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: You're an ass, you must have all things construed,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, and pierced too,
Or I find little pleasure.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Now you are knavish,
Go too, fetch Rowland hither presently,
Your twenty pound lies bleeding else: she is married
Within these twelve hours, if we cross it not,
And see the papers of one size.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I have ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: And for disposing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If I fail you
Now I have found the way, use martial law
And cut my head off with a hand saw:

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Well sir.
Petronius and Moroso I'll see sent for
About your business; go.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I am gone. Exit Tra.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Ho Livia. Enter Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: A friend of yours, lord how you look now,
As if you had lost a Carrick.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O Byancha.
I am the most undone, unhappy woman.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Be quiet wench, thou shalt be done, and done,
And done, and double done, or all shall split for't,
No more of these minced passions, they are mangy,
And ease thee of nothing, but a little wind,
An apple will do more: thou fearest Moroso.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Even as I fear the gallows.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Keep thee there still.
And you love Rowland? say.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If I say not
I am sure I lie.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: What wouldst thou give that woman,
In spite of all his anger, and thy fear,
And all thy father's policy, that could
Clap ye within these two nights quietly
Into a bed together?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Why fairly,
At half sword man and wife: now the red blood comes,
I marry now the matters changed.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Byancha,
Methinks you should not mock me.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Mock a pudding.
I speak good honest English, and good meaning.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I should not be ungrateful to that woman.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I know thou wouldst not, follow but my counsel
And if thou hast him not, despite of fortune
Let me never know a good night more; you must
Be very sick o'th instant.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Well, what follows?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: And in that sickness send for all your friends,
Your father, and your favour old Moroso,
And Rowland shall be there too.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What of these?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Do you not twitter yet? of this shall follow
That which shall make thy heart leap, and thy lips
Venture as many kisses, as the merchants
Do dollars to the East-indies: you shall know all,
But first walk in, and practise, pray be sick.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I do believe you: and I am sick.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Do
To bed then, come, I'll send away your servants
Post for your fool, and father; and good fortune,
As we mean honesty, now strike an upshot. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay, on my conscience, I have lost my money,
But that's all one: I'll never more persuade you,
I see you are resolute, and I commend you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But did she send for me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You dare believe me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot tell, you have your ways for profit
Allowed you Tranio, as well as I
Have to avoid 'em fear:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, on my word sir
L deal directly with you. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How now fellow,
Whither post you so fast?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O sir my master
Prey did you see my master?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why your master?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir his jewel.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: With the gilded button?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My pretty mistress Livia.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Is fallen sick o'th sudden.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How o'th sullens?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O'th sudden sir, I say, very sick:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: It seems she hath got the toothache with raw apples.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: It seems you have got the headache, fare you well sir.
You did not see my master?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, no, he did not see him.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell blue bottle. Exit servant.
What should her sickness be?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For you it may be.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes when my brains are out, I may believe it,
Never before I am sure: yet I may see her
'Twill be a point of honesty:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It will so.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: It may be not too: you would fain be fingering
This old sin-offering of two hundred, Tranio,
How daintily, and cunningly you drive me
Up like a deer to'th toil, yet I may leap it,
And what's the woodman then?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A looser by you.
Speak will you go or not? to me 'tis equal.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come what goes less?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay not a penny Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Shall I have liberty of conscience
Which by interpretation, is ten kisses?
Hang me if I affect her: yet it may be,
This whoreson manners will require a struggling,
Of two and twenty, or by’r lady thirty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: By’r lady I'll require my wager then,
For if you kiss so often, and no kindness,
I have lost my speculation, I'll allow you —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Speak like a gamester now.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It may be two.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Under a dozen Tranio 'There's no settings,
You shall have forty shillings, wink at small faults.
Say I take twenty, come, by all that's honest
I do it but to vex her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I'll no by-lowes.
If you can love her do, if you can hate her,
Or any else that loves you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Prithee Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why farewell twenty pound, 'twill not undo me;
You have my resolution.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And your money,
Which since you are so stubborn, if I forfeit,
Make me a jack of Lent, and break shins
For untagged points and compters: I'll go with you,
But if thou get'st a penny by the bargain;
A parting kiss is lawful?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I allow it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Knock out my brains with apples; yet a bargain:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I tell you, I'll no bargains; win, and wear it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou art the strangest fellow.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Along then, twenty pound more if thou dar'st,
I give her not a good word.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not a penny. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prithee, entreat her come, I will not trouble herExit Pedro.
Above a word or two; ere I endure
This life, and with a woman, and a vowed one
To all the mischiefs she can lay upon me,
I'll go to plough again, and eat leek porridge;
Begging's a pleasure to 't not to be numbered:
No there be other countries Jaques for me, and other people, yea, and other women.
If I have need, here's money, there's your ware,
Which is fair dealing, and the sun, they say
Shines as warm there, as here, and till I have lost
Either myself, or her, I care not whether
Nor which first.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Will your worship hear me?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And utterly outworn the memory
Of such a curse as this, none of my nation
Shall ever know me more.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Out alas sir
What a strange way do you run?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Any way,
So I outrun this rascal.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Methinks now,
If your good worship could but have the patience.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: The patience, why the patience?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Why I'll tell you,
Could you but have the patience.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well the patience.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: To laugh at all she does, or when she rails,
To have a drum beaten o'th top o'th house,
To give the neighbour's warning of her 'larm,
As I do when my wife rebels.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thy wife?
Thy wife's a pigeon to her a mere slumber,
The dead of night's not stiller.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Nor an iron mill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: But thy wife is certain.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That's false doctrine,
You never read of a certain woman.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou knowest her way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I should do, I am sure.
I have ridden it night, and day, this twenty year.

sp.speaker: Petri.
sp.l: But mine is such a drench of balderdash,
Such a strange carded cunningness, the rainbow
When she hangs bent in heaven, sheds not her colours
Quicker and more than this deceitful womanEnter Ped.
Weaves in her dyes of wickedness: what says she?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay not a word sir, but she pointed to me,
As though she meant to follow; pray sir bear it
E'en as you may, I need not teach your worship,
The best men have their crosses, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What ails the fellow?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And no doubt she may sir

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What may she, or what does she, or what is she?
Speak and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: She's mad sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Heaven continue it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Amen if't be his pleasure

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How mad is she?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As mad as heart can wish sir: she has dressed herself
(Saving your worship's reverence) just i'th cut
Of one of those that multiply i'th suburbs
For single money, and as dirtily:
If any speak to her, first she whistles,
And then begins her compass with her fingers,
And points to what she would have.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What new way's this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There came in master Sophocles,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And what
Did master Sophocles when he came in?
Get my trunks ready sirrah, I'll be gone straight.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He's here to tell youEnter Sophocles.
She's horn mad Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Call ye this a woman?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes sir, she is a woman,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Sir, I doubt it.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I had thought you had make experience,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes I did so.
And almost with my life.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You rid too fast sir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray be not mistaken: by this hand
Your wife's as chaste, and honest as a virgin,
For any thing I know: 'tis true she gave me
A ring.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For rutting.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You are much deceived still,
Believe me, I never kissed her since, and now
Coming in visitation, like a friend,
I think she is mad sir, suddenly she started,
And snatched the ring away, and drew her knife out,
To what intent I know not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Is this certain?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: As I am here sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I believe you honest. Enter Maria.
And pray continue so.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She comes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now damsel,
What will your beauty do, if I forsake you?
Do you deal by signs, and tokens? as I guess then,
You'll walk abroad, this summer, and catch captains,
Or hire a piece of holy ground i'th suburbs,
And keep a nest of nuns?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O do not stir her!
You see in what a case she is?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She is dogged,
And in a beastly case I am sure: I'll make her
If she have any tongue, yet tattleSophocles
Prithee observe this woman seriously,
And eye her well, and when thou hast done, but tell me
(For thou hast understanding) in what case
My sense was, when I chose this thing.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I'll tell you
I have seen a sweeter —

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: An hundred times cry oysters.
There's a poor beggar wench about Blackfriars
Runs on her breech may be an empress to her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Nay, now you are too bitter.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Never a whit sir:
I'll tell thee woman; for now I have day to see thee,
And all my wits about me, and I speak
Not out of passion neither (Leave your mumping)
I know you're well enough: now would I give
A million but to vex her: when I chose thee
To make a bedfellow, I took more trouble,
Than twenty terms can come too, such a cause
Of such a title, and so everlasting
That Adam's genealogy may be ended
Ere any law find thee: I took a leprosy,
Nay worse, the plague, nay worse yet, a possession
And had the devil with thee, if not more:
And yet worse, was a beast, and like a beast
Had my reward, a jade to fling my fortunes;
For who that had but reason to distinguish
The light from darkness, wine from water, hunger
From full satiety, and fox from fern bush
That would have married thee?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She is not so ill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She's worse than I dare think of: she's so lewd,
No court is strong enough to bear her cause.
She hath neither manners, honesty, behaviour,
Wifehood, nor womanhood, nor any moral
Can force me think she had a mother, no
I do believe her steadfastly, and know her
To be a woman-wolf by transmigration,
Her first form was a ferret's underground,
She kills the memories of men: not yet?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Do you think she's sensible of this?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I care not,
Be what she will the pleasure I take in her,
Thus I blow off, the care I took to love her,
Like this point I untie, and thus I lose it,
The husband I am to her, thus I sever:
My vanity farewell: yet, for you have been
So near me as to bear the name of wife,
My unquenched charity shall tell you thus much
(Though you deserve it well) you shall not beg,
What I ordained your jointure, honestly
You shall have settled on you: and half my house,
The other half shall be employed in prayers,
(That meritorious charge I'll beat also
Yet to confirm you christian) your apparel,
And what belongs to build up such a folly,
Keep I beseech you, it infects our uses,
And now I am for travel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now I love you,
And now I see you are a man I'll talk to you,
And I forget your bitterness.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: O Pliny, if thou wilt be ever famous
Make but this woman all thy wonders.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sure sir
You have hit upon a happy course, a blessed,
And what will make you virtuous?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She'll ship me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A way of understanding I long wished for,
And now 'tis come, take heed you fly not back sir,
Methinks you look a new man to me now,
A man of excellence, and now I see
Some great design set in you: you may think now
(And so may most that know me) 'twere my part
Weakly to weep your loss, and to resist you,
Nay hang about your neck and like a dotard
Urge my strong tie upon you: but I love you,
And all the world shall know it, beyond woman,
And more prefer the honour of your country,
Which chiefly you are born for, and may perfect,
The uses you may make of other nations,
The ripening of your knowledge, conversation,
The full ability, and strength of judgement,
Than any private love, or wanton kisses.
Go worthy man, bring home understanding.

sp.speaker: So●h.
sp.l: This were an excellent woman to breed schoolmen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For if the merchant through unknown seas plough
To get his wealth, than dear sir, what must you
To gather wisdom? go, and go alone,
Only your noble mind for your companion,
And if a woman may win credit with you,
Go far: too far you cannot: still the farther
The more experience finds you: and go sparing,
One meal a week will serve you, and one suit,
Through all your travels: for you'll find it certain,
The poorer and the baser you appear,
The more you look through still.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Dost hear her?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What would this woman do if she were suffered,
Upon a new adventure?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Make us nothing,
I wonder that she writes not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then when time,
And fullness of occasion have new made you,
And squared you from a sot into a signior,
Or nearer from a lade into a courser;
Come home an aged man, as did Ulysses,
And I your glad Penelope.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: That must have
As many lovers as I languages,
And what she does with one i'th day, i'th night
Undo it with another.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Much that way sir;
For in your absence, it must be my honour,
That, that must make me spoken of hereafter,
To have temptations, and not little ones
Daily and hourly offered me, and strongly,
Almost believed against me, to set off
The faith, and loyalty of her that loves you

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What should I do?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why by my — I would travel,
Did not you mean so?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Alas no, nothing less man:
I did it but to try sir, she's the devil,
And now I find it, for she drives me, I must go:
Are my trunks down there, and my horses ready?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, for your house, and if you please to trust me
With that you leave behind.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Bring down the money.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I am able, and to my poor fortunes,
I'll govern as a widow: I shall long
To hear of your welldoing, and your profit:
And when I hear not from you once a quarter,
I'll wish you in the Indies, or Cataya,
Those are the climes must make you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How's the wind?
She'll wish me out o'th world anon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For France.
'Tis very fair; get you aboard tonight sir,
And lose no time, you know the tide stays no man,
I have cold meats ready for you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Far thee well.
Thou hast fooled me o'th kingdom with a vengeance,
And thou canst fool me in again.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not I sir,
I love you better, take your time, and pleasure.
I'll see you horsed.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I think thou wouldst see me hanged too,
Were I but half as willing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Any thing
That you think well of, I dare look upon.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You'll bear me to the lands end Sophocles,
And other of my friends I hope.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never doubt sir,
You cannot want companions for your good:
I am sure you'll kiss me ere I go; I have business,
And stay long here I must not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Get thee going.
For if thou tarriest but another dialogue
I'll kick thee to thy chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Far you well sir,
And bear yourself, I do beseech you once more,
Since you have undertaken doing wisely,
Manly, and worthily, 'tis for my credit,
And for those flying fames here of your follies,
Your gambols, and ill breeding of your youth,
For which I understand you take this travel,
Nothing should make me leave you else, I'll deal
So like a wife, that loves your reputation,
And the most large addition of your credit,
That those shall die: if you want lemon-waters,
Or any thing to take the edge o'th sea off,
Pray speak, and be provided.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now the devil,
That was your first good master, shower his blessing
Upon ye all: into whose custody —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do commit your reformation,
And so I leave you to your stilo novo. Exit Maria

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I will go: yet I will not: once more Sophocles
I'll put her to the test.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You had better go.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I will go then: let's seek my father out,
And all my friends to see me fair aboard:
Then women, if there be a storm at sea,
Worse than your tongues can make, and waves more broken
Than your dissembling faiths are, let me feel
Nothing but tempests, till they crack my keel.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, and Byancha with four papers.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Now whether I deserve that blame you gave me,
Let all the world discern sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: If this motion,
(I mean this fair repentance of my daughter)
Spring from your good persuasion, as it seems so,
I must confess I have spoke too boldly of you,
And I repent.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: The first touch was her own,
Taken no doubt from disobeying you,
The second I put to her, when I told her
How good, and gentle yet, with free contrition
Again you might be purchased: loving woman,
She heard me, and I thank her, thought me worthy
Observing in this point: yet all my council,
And comfort in this case, could not so heal her
But that grief got his share too, and she sickened.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I am sorry she's so ill, yet glad her sickness
Has got so good a ground. Enter Moroso.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Here comes Moroso.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: O you are very welcome,
Now you shall know your happiness.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am glad on't.
What makes this lady here?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: A dish for you sir
You'll thank me for hereafter.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: True Moroso,
Go get you in, and see your mistress.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: She is sick sir,
But you may kiss her whole.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Comfort her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Why am I sent for sir?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Will you in, and see?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: May be she needs confession.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: By st. Mary,
She shall have absolution then and penance,
But not above her carriage.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Get you in fool. Exit. Mor.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Here comes the other too. En. Rowland and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now Tranio.
Good e'en to you too, and you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I have a certain daughter.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Would you had sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: No doubt you know her well.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Nor never shall sir.
She is a woman, and the ways unto her
Are like the finding of a certain path
After a deep fallen snow.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Well that's by'th by still.
This daughter that I tell you of is fallen
A little crop sick, with the dangerous surfeit
She took of your affection.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Mine sir?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes sir.
Or rather, as it seems, repenting.
And there she lies within, debating on't,

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I think 'twere well you would see her.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: If you please sir;
I am not squeamish of my visitation.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: But, this I'll tell you, she is altered much,
You'll find her now another Livia.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have enough o'th old sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: No more fool,
To look gay babies in your eyes young Rowland,
And hang about your pretty neck.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
And thank my fates I have scaped such execution,

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: And buss you till you blush again.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: That's hard sir,
She must kiss shamefully ere I blush at it,
I never was so boyish; well, what follows?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: She's mine now, as I please to settle her,
At my command, and where I please to plant her:
Only she would take a kind of farewell of you,
And give you back a wand'ring vow or two,
You left in pawn; and two or three slight oaths
She lent you too, she looks for.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She shall have 'em
With all my heart sir, and if you like it better,
A free release in writing.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: That's the matter,
And you from her, you shall have another Rowland,
And then turn tail to tail, and peace by with you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: So be it: your twenty pound sweats Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Twill not undo me Rowland, do your worst.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come, shall we see her sir?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Whate'er she says
You must bear manly Rowland, for her sickness
Has made her somewhat teatish.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let her talk
Till her tongue ache I care not: by this hand
Thou hast a handsome face wench, and a body
Daintily mounted; now do I feel an hundred
Running directly from me, as I pissed it.
sp.stage: Enter Livia discovered a-bed, and Moroso by her.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Pray draw 'em softly, the least hurry sir
Puts her to much impatience.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How is't daughter?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O very sick, very sick, yet somewhat
Better I hope; a little lightsommer,
Because this goodman has forgiven me;
Pray set me higher; o my head:

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Well done wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Father, and all good people that shall hear me,
I have abused this man perniciously; was never old man humbled so;
I have scorned him, and called him nasty names,
I have spit at him,
Flung candles ends in's beard, and called him harrow,
That must be drawn to all he dos: contemned him,
For methought then he was a beastly fellow.
(O God my side) a very beastly fellow.
And gave it out, his cassock was a barge-cloth,
Pawned to his predecessor by a sculler,
The man yet living: I gave him purging-comfits
At a great christening once,
That spoiled his chamblet breeches; and one night
I strewed the stairs with pease, as he passed down;
And the good gentleman (Woe worth me for't)
E'en with his reverent head, this head of wisdom,
Told two and twenty stairs, good and true;
Missed not a step, and as we say verbatim
Fell to the bottom, broke his casting bottle,
Lost a fair toadstone of some eighteen shillings,
Jumbled his joints together, had two stools,
And was translated. All this villainy
Did I: I Livia, I alone, untaught.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And I unasked, forgive it.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Where's Byancha?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Here cousin.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Give me drink,

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Rowland.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O'my dissembler, you and I must part.
Come nearer sir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am sorry for your sickness.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Be sorry for yourself sir, you have wronged me,
But I forgive you; are the papers ready?

sp.speaker: Bya
sp.l: I have 'em here: wilt please you view 'em?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Show 'em the young man too, I know he's willing
To shift his sails too: 'tis for his more advancement;
Alas, we might have beggared one another;
We are young both, and a world of children
Might have been left behind to curse our follies:
We had been undone Byancha, had we married,
Undone for ever: I confess I loved him,
I care not who shall know it, most entirely;
And once, upon my conscience, he loved me;
But farewell that, we must be wiser cousin.
Love must not leave us to the world: have you done?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes, and am ready to subscribe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pray stay then:
Give me the papers, and let me peruse 'em,
And so much time, as may afford a tear
At our last parting.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Pray retire, and leave her,
I'll call ye presently.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, the shower must fall.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Would I had never seen her.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou hast done bravely wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pray heaven it prove so.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There are the other papers: when they come
Begin you first, and let the rest subscribe
Hard by your side; give 'em as little light
As drapers do their wares.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: Didst mark Moroso,
In what an agony he was, and how he cried most
When I abused him most?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That was but reason.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O what a stinking thief is this?
Though I was but to counterfeit, he made me
Directly sick indeed. Thames-street to him
Is a mere pomander.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Let him be hanged.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: And lie you still.
And once more to your business.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Call 'em in.
Now if there be a power that pities lovers,
Help now, and hear my prayers.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Is she ready?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: She has done her lamentations: pray go to her.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Rowland, come near me, and before you seal,
Give me your hand: take it again; now kiss me,
This is the last acquaintance we must have;
I wish you ever happy: there's the paper.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Let me never live more
But I do begin to pity this young fellow;
How heartily he weeps!

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There's pen and ink sir.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: E'en here I pray you. 'tis a little emblem
How near you have been to me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There ..

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Your hands too,
As witnesses.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: By any means
To th' book son.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You must deliver it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There Livia, and a better love light on thee,
I can no more.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: To this you must be witness too.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Do you deliver it now.

sp.speaker: Lyv.
sp.l: Pray set me up;
There Rowland, all thy old love back: and may
A new to come exceed mine, and be happy.
I must no more.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell:

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A long farewell. Exit Rowl.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Leave hereby any means, till this wild passion
Be off her head; draw all the curtains close,
A day hence you may see her, 'twill be better,
She is now for little company.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Pray tend her.
I must to horse straight: you must needs along too,
To see my son aboard; were but his wife
As fit for pity, as this wench, I were happy.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Time must do that too: fare ye well; tomorrow
You shall receive a wife to quit your sorrow. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Jaques, Pedro, and porters, with chest and hampers.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: Bring 'em away sirs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Must the great trunks go too

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes, and the hampers; nay be speedy masters;
He'll be at sea before, us else.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques,
What a most blessed turn hast thou?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To have the sea between thee and this woman,
Nothing can drown her tongue, but a storm.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: By your leave,
We'll get us up to Paris with all speed;
For on my soul, as far as Amiens
She'll carry blank; away to lion key
And ship 'em presently, we'll follow ye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now could I wish her in that trunk:

sp.speaker: Jaq
sp.l: God shield man,
I had rather have a bear in't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes, I'll tell ye:
For in the passage if a tempest take ye,
As many do, and you lie beating for it,
Then, if it pleased the fates, I would have the master
Out of a powerful providence, to cry,
Lighten the ship of all hands, or we perish;
Then this for one, as best spared, should by all means
Overboard presently.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: On that condition,
So we were certain to be rid of her,
I would wish her with us: but believe me Pedro,
She would spoil the fishing on this coast for ever,
For none would keep her company, but dogfish,
As currish as herself; or porpoises,
Made to all fatal uses: the two fish-streets
Were she but once arrived amongst the whitings,
Would sing a woeful misereri Pedro,
And mourn in poor John, till her memory
Were cast of shore again, with a strong sea-breach:
She would make god Neptune, and his fire-fork,
And all his demigods, and goddesses,
As weary of the Flemish channel Pedro,
As ever boy was of the school: 'tis certain,
If she but meet him fair, and were well angered,
She would break his godhead.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O her tongue, her tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Rather her many tongues.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Or rather strange tongues.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her lying tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Her lisping tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her long tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Her lawless tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her loud tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And her liquorish —

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Many other tongues, and many stranger tongues
Than ever Babel had to tell his ruins,
Were women raised withal; but never a true one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Home with your stuff again; the journeys ended.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What does your worship mean?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Your master, oh Petruchio, oh poor fellows.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O your, master's dead,
His body coming back; his wife, his devil;
The grief of — her

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Has killed him?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Killed him, killed him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is there no law to hang her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Get ye in,
And let her know her misery, I dare not
For fear impatience seize me, see her more,
I must away again: bid her for wifehood,
For honesty, if she have any in her,
Even to avoid the shame that follows her.
Cry if she can: your weeping cannot mend it.
The body will be here within this hour, so tell her;
And all his friends to curse her. Farewell fellows.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: O my worthy master.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O my most beastly mistress, hang her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Split her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Drown her directly.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Starve her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Stink upon her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Stone her to death: may all she eat be eggs,
Till she run kicking mad for men.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And he,
That man, that gives her remedy, pray heaven
He may e'en ipso facto, lose his longings.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Let's go discharge ourselves, and he that serves her,
Or speaks a good word of her from this hour,
A seagly curse light on him, which is, Pedro;
The fiend ride through him booted, and spurred, with a sith at's back. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Rowland, and Tranio stealing behind him.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What a dull ass was I to let her go thus?
Upon my life she loves me still: well paper,
Thou only monument of what I have had,
Thou all the love now left me, and now lost,
Let me yet kiss her hand, yet take my leave
Of what I must leave e'er farewell Livia.
O bitter words, I'll read ye once again,
And then for ever study to forget ye.
How's this? let me look better on 't: a contract?
— a contract, sealed, and ratified,
Her father's hand set to it, and Moroso's
I do not dream sure, let me read again,
The same still: 'tis a contract.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis so Rowlands;
And by the virtue of the same, you pay me
An hundred pound tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Art sure Tranio,
We are both alive now?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Wonder not, ye have lost.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: If this be true, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis most certain,
There's a ring for you to, you know it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: When shall I have my money?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Stay ye, stay ye,
When shall I marry her?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Tonight .

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Take heed now
You do not trifle me; if you do,
You'll find more payment, than your money comes to:
Come swear; I know I am a man, and find
I may deceive myself: swear faithfully,
Swear me directly, am I Rowland?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Am I awake?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ye are.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Am I in health?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: As far as I conceive.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Was I with Livia?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You were, and had his contract.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And shall I enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, if ye dare.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Swear to all these.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: As thou art honest, as thou hast a conscience,
As that may wring thee if thou liest; all these
To be no vision, but a truth, and serious.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then by my honesty, and faith, and conscience;
All this is certain.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let's remove our places.
Swear it again.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: By — 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have lost then, and heaven knows I am glad out.
Let's go, and tell me all, and tell me how,
For yet I am a pagan in it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I have a priest too,
And all shall come as even as two testers. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, Sophocles, Moroso, and Petruchio born in a coffin.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Set down the body, and one call her out.
sp.stage: Enter Maria in black, and Jaques.
sp.l: You are welcome to the last cast of your fortunes;
There lies your husband, there your loving husband,
There he that was Petruchio, too good for ye;
Your stubborn, and unworthy way has killed him
Ere he could reach the sea; if ye can weep,
Now ye have cause begin, and after death
Do something yet to th'world, to think ye honest.
So many tears had saved him, shed in time;
And as they are (So a good mind go with 'em)
Yet they may move compassion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray ye all hear me,
And judge me as I am, not as you covet,
For that would make me ye more miserable:
'Tis true, I have cause to grieve, and mighty cause;
And truly and unfeignedly I weep it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I see there's some good nature yet left in her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But what's the cause? mistake me not, not this man,
As he is dead, I weep for; heaven defend it,
I never was so childish: but his life,
His poor unmanly wretched foolish life,
Is that my full eyes pity, there's my mourning.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Dost thou not shame?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do, and even to water,
To think what this man was, to think how simple,
How far below a man, how far from reason,
From common understanding, and all gentry,
While he was living here he walked amongst us.
He had a happy turn he died; I'll tell ye,
These are the wants I weep for, not his person:
The memory of this man, had he lived
But two years longer, had begotten more follies,
Then wealthy autumn flies: but let him rest,
He was a fool, and farewell he; not pitied,
I mean in way of life, or action
By any understanding man that's honest;
But only in's posterity, which I
Out of the fear his ruins might out live him
In some bad issue, like a careful woman,
Like one indeed born only to preserve him,
Denied him means to raise.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Unbutton me,
— I die indeed else? O Maria,
O my unhappiness, my misery.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Go to him whore; — if he perish,
I'll see thee hanged myself.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why, why Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have done my worst, and have my end, forgive me;
From this hour make me what you please: I have tamed ye,
And now am vowed your servant: look not strangely,
Nor fear what I say to you. Dare you kiss me?
Thus I begin my new love.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Once again?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Once again Miria!
O gentlemen, I know not where I am.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Get ye to bed then: there you'll quickly know sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Never no more your old tricks?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You shall not need, for as I have a faith
No cause shall give occasion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I am honest,
And as I am a maid yet, all my life
From this hour since, since ye make so free profession,
I dedicate in service to your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I marry, this goes roundly off.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Go Jaques,
Get all the best meat may be bought for money,
And let the hogsheads blood, I am born again:
Well little England, when I see a husband
Of any other nation stern or jealous,
I'll wish him but a woman of thy breeding,
And if he have not butter to thy bread,
Till thy teeth bleed, I'll never trust my travel.

div.stage: Enter Rowland, Livia, Byancha, and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Another morris, sir.
That you must pipe too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A poor married couple
Desire an offering sir.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Never frown at it,
You cannot mend it now: there's your own hand;
And yours Moroso, to confirm the bargain.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: My hand?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or mine?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You'll find it so.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A trick.
By — a trick.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes sir, we tricked ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Hast thou lyen with him? speak?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes truly sir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: And hast thou done the deed boy?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have done sir,
That, that will serve the turn, I think.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: A match then,
I'll be the maker up of this: Moroso,
There's now no remedy you see, be willing;
For be, or be not, he must have the wench.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Since I am overreached, let's in to dinner,
And if I can I'll drink't away.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Well sirrah, you have played a trick, look to't,
And let me be a grandsire within's twelvemonth,
Or by this hand, I'll curtail half your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There shall not want my labour sir: your money;
Here's one has undertaken.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well, I'll trust her,
And glad I have so good a pawn.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I'll watch ye.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Let's in, and drink of all hands, and be jovial:
I have my colt again, and now she carries;
And gentlemen, whoever marries next,
Let him be sure he keep him to his text. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Ladies to you, in whose defence and right,
Fletcher's brave muse prepared herself to fight
A battle without blood, 'twas well fought too,
(The victory's yours, though got with much ado.)
We do present this comedy, in which
A rivulet of pure wit flows, strong and rich
In fancy, language, and all parts that may
Add grace and ornament to a merry play.
Which this may prove. Yet not to go too far
In promises from this our female war,
We do entreat the angry men would not
Expect the mazes of a subtle plot,
Set speeches, high expressions; and what's worse,
In a true comedy, politic discourse.
The end we aim at, is to make you sport;
Yet neither gall the city, nor the court.
Hear, and observe his comic strain and when
You're sick of melancholy, see't again.
'Tis no dear physic, since 'twill quit the cost:
Or his intentions, with our pains, are lost.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: The tamer's tamed, but so, as nor the men
Can find one just cause to complain of, when
They fitly do consider in their lives,
They should not reign as tyrants o'er their wives.
Nor can the women from this precedent
Insult, or triumph: it being aptly meant,
To teach both sexes due equality;
And as they stand bound, to love mutually.
If this effect, arising from a cause
Well laid, and grounded, may deserve applause,
We something more than hope, our honest ends
Will keep the men, and women too, our friends.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
